reviewText:
I bought this game to play multiplayer with my girlfriend, after we beat Diablo 3. Honestly, it was some of the most frustrating gaming I've ever experienced, and if it wasn't for the fact that not many other games of this genre exist, I would've uninstalled it ages ago.

Pros:
- nice atmosphere and art
- interesting character builds
- decent story and voice acting
- the game looks great and runs pretty well - no sudden slowdowns or anything like that

Cons:
- frequent crashing/locking up when doing scene transitions, to the point where we were lucky to play 2h at a time
- frequent bugs that interrupt the gameplay (ie you are dead and can't respawn, or you respawn in your home-base but are dead and need resurrecting *in the base*)
- bugs that break missions (had en entire level bug out with no enemies spawning over multiple visits/session, broke the final boss quest 3 or 4 times)
- ridiculous difficulty. maybe we were playing it wrong after Diablo but dying constantly on Casual difficulty was not fun
- as a spellcaster, I had frequent lock-ups where a spell would remain stuck casting, so I couldn't cast any other spells and could not move - had to just wait to die and respawn

Not sure how that stacks up in single-player since I was not interested in that aspect, so if you're never intending to play multiplayer read some other reviews. However, if you want to play multiplayer, I hope you have endless patience.

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is very reminiscent of the legendary Diablo II, an action RPG combining both alot & fast action with character progression. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing captures the return of Van Helsing junior to Eastern Europe in order to aid the people of Borgovia in their fight against evil. I didn't get really hooked by the storyline, but the action keeps you moving forward. While there is quite some decent game time before you finish the game, the plot seems rather unfinished. Guess we need to wait until the follow-up game arrives.
Bought the game during a Steam sale, which included all three content DLC. The Blue Blood DLC was particularly useful as it improves the usability of Katerina, your ghostly sidekick. Both Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic DLC just add two new classes to play with instead of the default Hunter class. I only played the Hunter class as there wasn't much incentive (expect the odd class side quests) to replay the game with another class. Overall, the game is warmly recommended for both new and experienced action RPG fans.

Score: 7.5/10

Pro:
+ character progression via skills, auras, perks, capabilities...
+ appealing visuals
+ Katerina your sidekick
+ choice between melee & ranged
+ loot, loot, loot!

Contra:
- character progression doesn't really matter, just stack melee or ranged skills and sweep through the game
- some bugs, e.g. traps not working, movies not playing (edit: fix was released after I finished the game)
- lots of crappy loot
- lack of replayability

reviewText: Great game!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Proof that Indie can be every bit as good as the best offerings from any AAA studio.  Great voice acting, great graphics, varied and interesting environments.

Sit back for a glorious, monster-filled romp through Borgivia.  Yes, the game has a lot in common with Diablo and Titan Quest - but that's a good thing:  Obliterating hoards of monsters and bagging a ton of loot is fun!  The story isn't anything special, but is solid enough.  The skill tree allows you to develop some interesting character builds - swordsman, gunslinger, magic user, or anything in-between.  Mid-way through the game, you're able to re-spec your character or Katerina at will, which gives you a chance to experiment with the various skills & builds.

Aside from the occasional obscured camera, I didn't experience any bugs or performance issues (I'm running Win 8.0), although I have seen a few complaints from others.

reviewText:
I was pleasantly surprised by Van Helsing.

At it's core it is a typical action RPG, kill waves of varying enemies as you fight towards a boss all while collecting loot and skill points.  Although it does have a few unique features that make it stand out in certain ways, such as a lair defense game which has you defending your secret base from waves of enemies with traps you can upgrade and strategically place about.

The story is great it kept me interested up until the end.  The AI companion is actually incredibly useful, she has a ton of useful skill points and a ton of options for adjusting her behaviour.

This game is not as complex as other Action RPG's, Path of Exile for example.  In my opinion it doesn't have a lot of replay value after you complete the story, there's a neverending mode where you can farm for high level items and multiplayer for playing with friends for those that do want to keep going though.

Definately worth picking up, it's a great game that pretty much anybody should be able to enjoy.

reviewText: Solid Hack&Slash, one of the better games of its kind that I've played. There's a lot of character advancement options, the writing is witty and fun, and the theme is pretty unique (a mixture of steampunk, gothic fiction and folklore undertones). Some slight innovations and experiments give the mechanics of this game a fresh and instantly recognizable feel.\n\nDespite many shortcomings and a general lack of polish in most places, fans of the genre should really check this one out. Keep in mind, however, that after finishing the campaign (which ends around the time you hit the level cap, which isn't too high at 30) there's not much left to do other than start a new character. A definite ending is a nice throwback to the original Diablo and personally, I enjoyed the fact that I can actually complete this game and it will acknowledge that, but I know that this may be an issue for many die-hard fans of the genre.

reviewText:
Proof that Indie can be every bit as good as the best offerings from any AAA studio.  Great voice acting, great graphics, varied and interesting environments.

Sit back for a glorious, monster-filled romp through Borgivia.  Yes, the game has a lot in common with Diablo and Titan Quest - but that's a good thing:  Obliterating hoards of monsters and bagging a ton of loot is fun!  The story isn't anything special, but is solid enough.  The skill tree allows you to develop some interesting character builds - swordsman, gunslinger, magic user, or anything in-between.  Mid-way through the game, you're able to re-spec your character or Katerina at will, which gives you a chance to experiment with the various skills & builds.

Aside from the occasional obscured camera, I didn't experience any bugs or performance issues (I'm running Win 8.0), although I have seen a few complaints from others.

reviewText:
The Good
Sure, this game is YADC - yet another Diablo clone: you walk around, meet hordes of interesting monsters, and slay them. They drop loot and gold, you pick it up, and either wear it or sell it. A tried-and-true recipe with little to improve on.
And yet... they managed. The ghost companion provides for rather amusing dialogue and banter, though her shopping spree quips do get old after a while. The setting is a classic, and well done, at that; the monsters are quite appropriate, and the Eastern-Slavic NPC's got at least a chuckle from me.

The Bad
Maps are pretty much static; while loot drops are mostly random, the only thing that changes are the shrines - not their position, but only their conferred bonuses. It might not be a big deal, but a touch of variety wouldn't hurt.

The Ugly
Without the DLC's you only get a third of the game: one character out of three. And you still get loot drops for the characters you're missing. So if you're buying, take that into account: whatever the game price, add in the price of all the DLC's.
This is not how DLC's should work, much as they often do.

reviewText:
I initially resisted buying this game because I thought it might be a lame movie tie-in game. However I decided to give it a shot after reading reviews. I was pleasantly surprised to find that it is a very good arpg game.

The game features standard arpg gameplay, well-adapted for using a controller. With dlc there are a few different classes, and different ways to build your character within those classes. The writing is good, with lots of clever banter between Van Helsing, his ghost companion, and sometimes the different characters you meet while adventuring. There are a few offbeat quests and amusing easter eggs to find. These touches help the game to stand out from the average hack n slash arpg. The action is top-notch. Mobs can be huge and overwhelming sometimes. The game definitely keeps you moving while in areas populated by enemies. This, combined with the large variety of monster types definitely keeps the game from getting repetitive. Monster respawn every time you leave an area. Fortunately the respawning can be turned off, and then can be turned on again if you feel you need to grind more xp before progressing further in the game.

Overall I'd give the entire series an 8.5/10. This and its sequel are first class modern arpgs, just as good as Diablo III or Torchlight II.

reviewText: A great start to a new franchise and one of the funnest, and funniest dungeon crawler RPG's I have ever played. Van Helsing and Katarina have great chemistry and quip with eachother the entire game and there is also plenty of humor and jokes hidden throughout. There are a few issues with the game that do hurt my rating of it, though. First, for a dungeon crawler it is pretty short, but it was meant to be a trilogy. Second, the game is very, VERY unbalanced. When the game begins it's simple enough and fun to play, but once you are a couple of hours in the difficulty ramps up out of nowhere and you are constantly dieing and respawning every few minutes and this lasts the rest of the game. Enemies seem to do ungodly amounts of damage and your stats or equipment don't seem to make any difference in how much damage you take or deal. It makes for a very frustrating experience in an otherwise top-notch RPG. I highly recommend it for the cheap going price.

reviewText: A ton of fun. If you liked Titan Quest, this feels like a spiritual successor. It's not very long, guessing around 20 hours. I got it for less than $7 though, and that's a great value. I'll probably replay it at some point as well. I'd say it's easily worth the price at full price too. It feels more engaging than your typical isometric arpg, especially playing at higher difficulties. They made most of the abilities have combinations, so you're constantly doing things. Unless you're playing the game on an easier difficulty, it shouldn't be a matter of spamming a single ability over and over (which is nice compared to a majority of these style games).\n\nThe leveling system feels nice. It's usually exciting to get a new level. There's also a reputation system, where you get to choose a new strong buff after gaining enough reputation. The reputation system felt a bit slow, though. I'm nearly at the end of the game and I've gotten around 6 levels in reputation. The loot system felt on-par with other games in this genre. I got the feeling that there weren't many set" items

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is one of a number of games released in the last few years that succesfully tackles a popular but well-worn genre, and manages to be both faithful to the genre style, whilst streamlining the experience, leaving it feeling both new and deeply nostalgic at the same time.

This game is one of the more fun isometric RPGs I've played, and I'd call myself a harsh critic of the genre. This and Torchlight 2 are probably my favourites, and share a lot in common in terms of updating and streamlining the experience. TIAVH is generally a well-made game, and despite some issues with player-character pathfinding, I can't really fault the production quality. It has wonderfully schlocky voice acting, humourous dialogue, lovely visuals, a deep, deep skill tree that you'll never completely discover in one playthorough, a streamlined inventory, tonnes of enemy types, plenty of wonderful locations, and LOTS of loot. The game also rewards you regularly with achievements, which keeps you pushing forward.

With that being said, it doesn't reinvent the wheel, meaning that some of the clunkier core mechanics of the isometric RPG classics remain intact. Expect repetition, a relentless onslaught of enemies, lots of useless loot, and sharp, frustrating spikes in difficulty, particularly towards the last 25% of the game.

While this does stick to a classic (and some might say tired) formula, the depth of the skill trees, the frequent validation by achievements, and the sheer personality of the characters and the world keep me playing onwards.

Even with any gripes I have towards genre, I'd recommend this for full price, as the sheer depth of content will surely leave you feeling satisfied with your purchase. I hear that the sequel is even better, and I can't wait to play it!

reviewText: I struggled with my rating on this game. It's at once terrible and kind of addicting. The dialog straddles the line between downright bad and intentionally campy. It's tough to tell for sure whether they meant for it to be as bad as it was.\n\nAs far as gameplay goes, it's a reasonable clone of Diablo mixed with some Torchlight. The lack of polish on the game was the deciding factor in giving it a Nay instead of Yay. Having the game simply end with no recognition that you've completed anything is tough to overlook. Add to that the MP crashing bugs and wonky key bindings and you have a take it/leave it game.

reviewText:
This game. Buy it. It's worth the full asking price - and that's high praise coming from me.

The story is fantastic, drawing you in and making you want to play more just to find out what comes next. The music is soulful, and haunting; the graphics quite good.

The game itself plays like Diablo and Torchlight, so if you've played either, you shouldn't have any problems with the controls and skill trees. The references to memes, other games, and popular culture are wide spread in this game. Everything from Ghostbusters to Portal and many more are alluded to here.

The only gripe that I have about the game is that the end boss was too easy to beat. I had more difficulty beating a lower level boss than I did the final one. But then, I did play single player and on easy difficulty, which probably affected things a bit. My next play through will be multiplayer and on a higher difficulty setting, so it should be a bit more challenging the next time through.

Again, this game is highly recommended.

reviewText:
The Incredible Lag of Van Helsing

Generally I don't write bad reviews about games, but this time I have to.

The main reason why I give this game negative score is because the technical aspect of this game is on the same level as that garbage of this game's steampunk scenery:

1. It is badly optimized
2. Quests get bugged all the time
3. Ability sets don't get saved
4. The game tends to crash after minimizing it

To eleborate:

1. You will need better hardware you think for this game to be playable, the recommended settings I can consider to be lies. Even if you tinker the settings to get FPS up, the game still suffers from annoying stuttering and screen-tearing. V-sync will dump your performance even more.

2. Scripts, gate openings, cutscene launches after booses - such quest related things routinely fail to execute, but hey - the devs got a solution"
date: open chat and type "/FixQuest" then space and a number
recommended: which quest needs fixing... it is better than nothing but such cheap solution is an insult to paying users - why the hell wasn't the game released in a proper condition in the first place?\n\n3. Similar to other hack and slash games

reviewText: With the plethora of options available to the modern ARPG connoisseur, Van Helsing finds itself an average product on a shelf packed with fantastic games at extremely reasonable prices. It's unfortunate, because I'm sure this game would've been considered great in 2004-2008. With Torchlight 2, Diablo 3, and Path of Exile easily available - all superior options, and all unique from each other - the generic and mediocre Van Helsing cannot be recommended in good conscience.

reviewText:
If you want more from your regular hack-n-slash RPG than just... well, hack and slash monsters and demons; that is, if you also want some good story, beautiful looking landscapes, and a dense and unique atmosphere, then this one could be for you, since it possesses all these properties. But... who knows for sure? Maybe you want even more than that these days to be convinced, something new from an old genre. Let's see...

Well...

- How about a good - and we mean GOOD - soundtrack, that perfectly - and we mean PERFECTLY - matches with that said unique atmosphere? Yes?
Check.

- How about some really nice voice acting (most of the time, at least), with European accent and all? Ok? You know van Helsing's environment is Europe, right? You remember Bram Stocker? Without google, that is. I hope so.
Ok, then, check.

- How about some little puzzles with ancient, sacred pagan objects in the middle of some frightening bog, infested with demonic beasts trying to tear your hat - and your head inside it - mercilessly apart? How about fighting some blood-thirsty, hellish fiends that jump over you out of the blue, cause you're trying to retrieve some legendary, holy, long hidden relic? How about answering some riddles - yes, we said riddles - from enigmatic NPC's, to which a wrong answer could mean a quick, but no less painful death?
Check those.

- How about some funny moments that will put a smile on your foolish face: funny references to famous games, books, movies, and characters every now and then?
Check this too.

You want all that, don't you? Man, then this game is definitely for you! Just grab it now, cause it have it all, you fool!

Then it is perfect?" you could ask. You know

reviewText: Very solid action RPG that's super addictive. Nothing particularly groundbreaking (apart from the sort-of tower defense bits), but it does everything well. Great banter between Van Helsing and your ghost companion Katarina. Great value for money.

reviewText:
Van Helsing started off as a very promising game.  I enjoyed the first third particularly as the side quests and various other things to find in the world kept the entertainment levels high.  The 2nd and 3rd chapters were less inspiring and the end boss was rather ordinary

Positives - the banter between Katrina and Van Helsing was worthwhile and entertaining.  There were lots of monsters to kill and the setting had atmosphere
Negatives - the skill trees were a little lack luster and I lost patience with the loot.  I also found the combat to be hectic and not really engaging

Worth a few dollars but I doubt whether I'd be playing through the game a second time.  That said, I'd probably buy the sequel at some point

reviewText: Van Helsing is an arpg fantasy game set in the not too distant past. You play as the son of Van Helsing and, like your father, you have a variety of spells, ranged weapons, and blade weapons at your disposal. The story isn’t great, but it’s also no worse than the stories in other arpgs. Van Helsing, the ghostly companion, and a few other notable characters have decent voice work, but the rest of the cast is plagued by lines likely composed by the programmers themselves. Most of the locations are graphically pleasing, but some appear slightly blurry (idk why???). The-game play is smooth and responsive; the enemies vary in aesthetics and behavior; and the progression system is elaborate and rewarding. Overall, the game at its core is great, but bugs, glitches, and oversights (see comment section) compound to drastically ravage the overall experience.\n\nThe Incredible Adventures Of Van Helsing: 7.5 / 10.0
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is no second coming of Diablo II, but it's a fun, funny action-RPG with occasional glimmers of innovation. Sure, it's fairly derivative overall, simplistic compared to genre kingpins, and weak in the co-op department, but obvious care went into its craft. Miraculously miniscule price tag or not, Van Helsing is a damn (and probably damned) solid game.

reviewText: Rating: 8/10\n\nThis game definitely belongs to the better half of the hack'n'slash RPG out there and has probably the best kind of humor amongst them all. Gameplay is really nice and smooth, with various skill tree (tricks/actives/passives/auras...) and many side-quests, hovewer, it's pretty short in comparison to other similar pieces. You can extend your game experience by playing single scenarious or start neverending story mode (something like NG+). If you decide to buy this game, I would recommend to get the DLC's as well, since they really add some nice features which original game lacks (new skill tree for Katarina, and most importantly, two new classes - Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic).

reviewText:
It is clearly not an AAA game, but it is a fun Diablo/Torchlight clone with an interesting story and adorable characters.

The graphics and sound are adequate and the combat is fun, there is some diversity in character builds, just don't expect much variety in combat.

The story, quests and dialogues are quite entertaining, but the game starts to feel a bit too grindy by the third act.

Overall, a decent Diablo clone that stands out for the atmosphere and the writing. Worth a run or two.

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing Complete Pack is a beautiful, isometric action-rpg that provides a challenging experience which has a sense of humor, an interesting companion system, satisfying combat, very buggy controller support, and some noteworthy differences from the base version.

There's a lot of quirky referential humor in the game that I do not want to spoil here. Just make sure to explore everywhere and talk to everyone and... everything, especially in the first town. The world is not grim dark; it has a joke or two up its sleeve.

Katarina, Van Helsing's companion, is very helpful and has very interesting ways to alter her behavior to fit your play style. She will level up with you and has her own set of skills, two with the DLC. You can also choose three different states for her which include ghost (peaceful), melee, and ranged. You can alter how aggressive she is with enemies. She can also pick up different items of varying rarities automatically according to player desires. I had her pick up all the gold, ignore the white items, pick up the magic items, and fight enemies in melee form. It is a neat feature that is greatly appreciated and should be present in more games with companions/followers.

The combat requires you to pay attention and engage its systems if success interests you. The game has a combo system that alters how a skill can be used. For example, Earthquake, a spell that deals damage in a line, has three different power-ups that can be used in a combo: Brutal Stomp which adds 1.5 meters to the skill's width, Intense Shockwave which adds 30% more damage, and Scorching Fumes which burns everything hit for 10% of Van Helsing's Spellpower. You can spend skill points on the ones you want and organize them in whatever order. You stack up to three combos with the a, s, and d keys resulting in a very powerful skill waiting to be used. I went with 90% additional damage for Earthquake with a high critical chance build to great effect. I could have gone with 1.5 meters to width and 60% additional damage. Other skills have different power-ups available for experimentation. You will be working with Katarina to dispose of monsters while using tricks to change the flow of battle. I often used the one that freezes time to give myself a chance to observe the situation and line up Earthquake perfectly, especially when fighting extremely large groups.

This game will test the average player's abilities, but the systems it has in place makes it forgiving and approachable. Despite dying a good dozen or so times during my time with the game, I only had to pay a bit of gold to resurrect and continue the battle against evil. There are also special npcs in towns that can refund skill points for both the player and Katarina should you want to try a different build or made a mistake in your allocations.

Do not use a controller with this game. Playing this game with a controller resulted in a frustrating battle with the user interface. Looking at the skill power-ups wouldn't work for skills at the bottom of the page and laying down certain traps did not turn out very well. The combat experience works well enough, but the UI problems are severe enough to just stick with mouse and keyboard. The UI for mouse and keyboard results in faster interactions for everything and lets you properly look at all the information available. I spent fifteen hours with this game using the controller until I finally decided to stop torturing myself. The last four hours were blissful.

Finally, the complete pack comes with three different pieces of DLC which includes an additional skill tree for Katarina known as Blue Blood and two more classes, Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic. The Blue Blood tree has some really powerful abilities that drastically change Katarina's performance. She could rival me in power and I do not know what I would have done without her. Blue Blood allows for major damage, health, and defense increases. It also gives her different passive spells that she can activate based on chance or even death for one of them (big explosion). It even adds an often used Trick called Ghostly Mirage which allows for two Katarina illusions that can deal damage. The two extra classes, basically a mage and a scientist/engineer, have one main skill tree and a heavily modified Tricks tree allowing for a different experience from the Hunter who wields swords and/or pistols with some magic. If the classes do not interest you, I still heavily recommend Blue Blood unless you want an extra challenging experience.

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good action-rpg that should entertain those familiar with the genre. Again, I am heavily recommending to not use a controller with this game.

reviewText: Excellent action/adventure game in the spirit of Diablo II. Solid story, very fun NPC interaction, interesting monsters.  Skill tree is intuitive and combat has lots of options without requiring a massive amount of complexity.  The DLC as not been to my preference, but you should check that out on your own to decide.  The multiplayer really reminds me a great deal of Diablo II.\n\nVery playful, fun and very entertaining.  It took about 20 minutes to come up to speed, then 15 minutes to adapt the controls and options to my preferences, and then I was off to the races.  The skill trees are varied enough to allow for multiple character classes" and then the 2 DLC options are also available.  The equipment has a wide range of randomized enchantments
date: with an additional enchant and "gem slots" available.\n\nWell designed
recommended: the gameplay is fluid and easy without being dull.  The story is strong and compelling
hoursPlayed: but leaves a bunch of exploration options so it does not feel railroaded.\n\nI recommend to anyone who enjoys fantasy action games."

reviewText: This was a fantastic buy during a Steam Sale when I first bought it, yeah it has some bugs and issues like any other PC game, but it's REALLY fun. Lots of people, including myself, like a challenge in a game, and being OP in a game is kind of boring. Not in this game, because you end up fighting hordes and hordes of enemies, so while you're OP against most enemies individually, you still get a good challenge to stay alive when fighting 50+ monsters clustering around you. The story is lacking some depth to it, the creators really focused on the dialogue between your main character and your companion, thus neglecting the story and creating something with more substance. Regardless, this is a great game to just kill things for fun, level up, and choose from a variety of playstyles and customization options. Oh, and did I mention you can get a GIANT FRICKIN LASER BEAM?!

reviewText:
Being a sucker for top-down action-rpgs, i HAD to have this game on release, and I don't regret it one bit, even if it did take me forever to beat it.

This game is a diablo style ARPG complete with tiered loot drops, character stat allocation, skill upgrades, and gems (essences) to put into slotted gear. There is even somewhat of a pet system. It is similar to Torchlight's, except your pet is your female busty-sidekick-follower. She has skills and stat points that you can upgrade, as well as limited gear allocation.

There are only 3 Acts, which took me a total of 26 hours to complete on the hardest difficulty. And DAMN was it challenging at times. I experimented with various builds (its easy to respec your character stats AND skills) until I found the right one to deal with huge hoards of mobs. You are going to be dealing with a screen full of enemies for most of this game, and they're going to want to kill you. Combat ended up being me running in to nuke a hoard of enemies, using potions, and kiting back until potion cooldowns were up. Rinse and repeat. It sounds bad, but I enjoyed it quite a bit. IT was only this difficult because I was playing on the hardest difficulty. I prefer games of this genre to be challenging as hell.

The story isn't anything spectacular, but the dialogue between the main character and his follower always made me smile. There is plenty humor in their banter, as well as the occaisional referential humor with quests.

I didn't try the multiplayer because I heard it was buggy. The graphics are ok and the music suits the game's style.

TLDR: Great game. I recommend it to every fan of the Diablo genre.

reviewText:
I picked this up a few weeks ago on sale and so far, have greatly enjoyed it.  It's an action rpg with surprisingly good character chemsitry and voice acting.  The interactions between the protagonist and his ghostly companion are well acted and entertaining.  The companion helps in combat, either through a ranged form, melee form, or passive form that grants you 10% damage resistance.

The skill system (for the primary Hunter character) is divided into 4 parts.  Melee, Ranged, Tricks, and Auras.  Melee and Ranged are self-explanatory.  Tricks give you spells that don't require mana but have a timer, that range from healing, to cloning your ghost, to ramming through your enemies.  Auras grant you passive improvements to your character.  One aspect I really enjoy of the skill system is the ability to upgrade your ghostly companion.  You can spec her to have skills that passively benefit you (such as increased magic find or defense) or enhance her damage and survivabilty.

Combat is a bit diferent in that you can enhance your skills with adrenaline.  Each skill offers 3 different side-grades that you can enhance your attack with all at once (e.g., +30% damage, +10% damage resistance, +10% length) or dump all of your adrenaline into one for maximum effect (e.g, +90% damage).  The combinations are interesting and even the early skills remain viable throughout the game.  Combat can be irratating because you are constantly being swarmed by gangs of monsters, so the focus tends to be more on crowd control than anything else.  As you progress through the story, some monsters are downright brutal and can kill you very quickly if you are not careful.

The story is on par for the genre and the setting, while appropriately grim, isn't anything spectacular.  There are a few bugs here and there, so be forewarned.  At times, the game will hang, which can be really annoying.  Generally it clears up but I have had to force-quit on at least one occassion.

With the vanilla pack, there is only the Hunter class.  While you can spec Van Helsing with all sorts of skills, if you want a pure magic based or technology based character, you will have to pay for them in separate DLC.

Bottom line:  If you like action RPGS, you will like The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing.  It's not perfect, but I think it has enough charm to help it stand out in the crowd.

reviewText:
Starting off, I was waiting for this game for a while. I love dark-themed RPGs and when i saw that its style is similar to Diablo II I was thrilled. So i bought it.
Gameplay: It's pretty simple. You have your melee weapon, a ranged one and spells. Each of these elements is affected by its own skill tree so you can customise your playstyle. Katarina is a useful companion with stances that are similar to the ones i said before and you can determine hers to your liking. The mobs have a variety of styles when it comes to appearance and aggresion and that is really good. Besides that, all is pretty much similar to the Diablo series: point n click, quests, looting and a camera that resembles Diablo's. The item variety is also huge and will allow you to customise your Hellsing anyway you want.
Sound: The music is extraordinary and it really taps you in the dark atmosphere the game has. The voice actors are awesome as well, I really couldn't think of someone better to voice Van Hellsing. Also, the small banters between Hellsing and Katarina sound natural and really funny.
Graphics: I couldn't find much about the game's engine only that it's custom made. Nevertheless, it doesn't have any particular requirements it's pretty light to play.
On the downside, after 30 hours of slaying mobs you might feel a bit bored and tired. After you get used to it, the game tends to become a bit repetitive where you have to go there, do that, talk to that guy, kill mobs and the circle begins anew. What left me dissapointed was the multiplayer though. It has some PVE elements but the basic idea is that you play the story from the beginning with 2 or 3 more guys in it helping you. The mobs are slightly tougher to beat but pretty much that is all. Oh, and the objectives of each mission in the storyline are for everyone not each Hellsing individually.

TL:DR: a really nice game waking Diablo II memories, it might get a bit repetitive after a while and the multiplayer could use some more work. Worth trying it.

reviewText:
Van Helsing is a very enjoyable hack and slash RPG. It may not offer endless replay value but you are almost certain to enjoy your first / second playthrough. So it offers 15-30 hours of fun at a very low price.

PS. I do advise to buy the katarina DLC. It helps to keep her alive and thereby make the game more fun to play.

+ good pace & difficulty level, lovely world with plenty of humor. Truly excellent item system offering just the right amount of loot to keep you playing just a little bit longer, if the Diablo III loot 2.0 is a bit like this, everybody will have a blast.
- The graphics itself are rather decent, but the spell effects are not that impressive. Some games in the genre offer nearly endless replay value, in Van Helsing that is less the case. After 1 playtrough you have the feeling you have seen it all. The only reason to keep playing is the loot.

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing Complete Pack is a beautiful, isometric action-rpg that provides a challenging experience which has a sense of humor, an interesting companion system, satisfying combat, very buggy controller support, and some noteworthy differences from the base version.

There's a lot of quirky referential humor in the game that I do not want to spoil here. Just make sure to explore everywhere and talk to everyone and... everything, especially in the first town. The world is not grim dark; it has a joke or two up its sleeve.

Katarina, Van Helsing's companion, is very helpful and has very interesting ways to alter her behavior to fit your play style. She will level up with you and has her own set of skills, two with the DLC. You can also choose three different states for her which include ghost (peaceful), melee, and ranged. You can alter how aggressive she is with enemies. She can also pick up different items of varying rarities automatically according to player desires. I had her pick up all the gold, ignore the white items, pick up the magic items, and fight enemies in melee form. It is a neat feature that is greatly appreciated and should be present in more games with companions/followers.

The combat requires you to pay attention and engage its systems if success interests you. The game has a combo system that alters how a skill can be used. For example, Earthquake, a spell that deals damage in a line, has three different power-ups that can be used in a combo: Brutal Stomp which adds 1.5 meters to the skill's width, Intense Shockwave which adds 30% more damage, and Scorching Fumes which burns everything hit for 10% of Van Helsing's Spellpower. You can spend skill points on the ones you want and organize them in whatever order. You stack up to three combos with the a, s, and d keys resulting in a very powerful skill waiting to be used. I went with 90% additional damage for Earthquake with a high critical chance build to great effect. I could have gone with 1.5 meters to width and 60% additional damage. Other skills have different power-ups available for experimentation. You will be working with Katarina to dispose of monsters while using tricks to change the flow of battle. I often used the one that freezes time to give myself a chance to observe the situation and line up Earthquake perfectly, especially when fighting extremely large groups.

This game will test the average player's abilities, but the systems it has in place makes it forgiving and approachable. Despite dying a good dozen or so times during my time with the game, I only had to pay a bit of gold to resurrect and continue the battle against evil. There are also special npcs in towns that can refund skill points for both the player and Katarina should you want to try a different build or made a mistake in your allocations.

Do not use a controller with this game. Playing this game with a controller resulted in a frustrating battle with the user interface. Looking at the skill power-ups wouldn't work for skills at the bottom of the page and laying down certain traps did not turn out very well. The combat experience works well enough, but the UI problems are severe enough to just stick with mouse and keyboard. The UI for mouse and keyboard results in faster interactions for everything and lets you properly look at all the information available. I spent fifteen hours with this game using the controller until I finally decided to stop torturing myself. The last four hours were blissful.

Finally, the complete pack comes with three different pieces of DLC which includes an additional skill tree for Katarina known as Blue Blood and two more classes, Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic. The Blue Blood tree has some really powerful abilities that drastically change Katarina's performance. She could rival me in power and I do not know what I would have done without her. Blue Blood allows for major damage, health, and defense increases. It also gives her different passive spells that she can activate based on chance or even death for one of them (big explosion). It even adds an often used Trick called Ghostly Mirage which allows for two Katarina illusions that can deal damage. The two extra classes, basically a mage and a scientist/engineer, have one main skill tree and a heavily modified Tricks tree allowing for a different experience from the Hunter who wields swords and/or pistols with some magic. If the classes do not interest you, I still heavily recommend Blue Blood unless you want an extra challenging experience.

The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a good action-rpg that should entertain those familiar with the genre. Again, I am heavily recommending to not use a controller with this game.

reviewText: This game is an action packed, button mashing, Werewolf horde of excitement. If you plan on getting this game make sure you have a good keyboard. It might be controller compatible, but it gets quite tedious and hard (you end up teleporting a lot when you don't mean to), so i suggest using a keyboard and setting all 92390280938902 key binds to things you will easily remember (even though I still don't know where everything is). There is a lot going on in this game, especially when trying to figure out what to do, what skills and spells to use, what to keep for your character and setting up your companion followers stuff too. This is a game you can't just jump right into and rule the world, it's confusing for new players, but don't give up on it because of the confusement, stick around, bash some buttons and eventually you will get the hang of it because it's a pretty cool game.\n\nEdit: Cool until you hit a bunch of bugged quests and can't go any further...

reviewText:
Okay, another game off my chest. Time logged? 28 hours - roughly 2 days of nonstop gaming. Compared to TL2/D3/Titan Quest, I would probably rank this behind TQ and quite far from TL2 or D3. I spent most of the time doing a few things. Reading the scripts, listening to the music, kiting, checking loot and constantly reading online to understand more on the game. The kiting part annoyingly reminds me of my D3 monk before I quit D3 entirely.

Pros:
*Script lines that are worth reading from time to time (Katarina and Helsing Jr. was fun to listen to)
*Tower/castle defense game was fun and rather cool albeit short (it could be better but oh well)
*Music by itself is enchanting and very well matched with the game theme (it comes with the game, I know cause I just copied them out)
*Rage points/factor makes the gameplay more interesting

Cons:
*Creeps are not respawned (limiting the farming/looting activities which is very funny considering the game is supposedly about loot and if you really must farm, the developer said that you need to either join a MP game and then go offline or play scenario mode instead)
*Lack of explanation on some portion of the game that forces you to Google it instead (e.g. WTF is scenario mode, or what differences does it make if I go online/offline???)
*Not much to replay again unless you want to farm achievements or try out the different skill build (which is rather bland/limited if not thanks to the rage usage)
*I hate the abrupt ending (developer said that there are future incoming chapters to the game, I say You should have told me earlier and you could at least end this chapter on better note")

Summary:
Worth the $15 (even better when discounted) but don't expect a TL2 quality type of game
date: it isn't. A bit glitchy/laggy and I got a random creep stuck halfway in the dungeon = unable to proceed with quest until I went back to kill it. Personal advice
recommended: play more on melee too (it will be painful but at least the crowd control is better and you will have more fun)."

reviewText:
In the world of top down RPG's, The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing adds some very interesting gameplay mechanics to the traditional Diablo, Path of Exile, Dungeon Siege style gameplay. Set in the lore of Van Helsing this game provides fans of the fiction a interactive world that they can journey through with friends. While this is just the first part of the trilogy, it holds it's own against games like Diablo III and Path of Exile as a enjoyable adventure. I highly recommend this title to any fan of Action RPG's.

Check out our Streams of Epic Adventure Episode 20 for a full look at this wonderful title.

reviewText:
In a market filled with many games focused in loot and quests it may be hard for some games to get the recognition they deserve and with The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing I can honestly say that it was such a pleasant surprise that I hope it’s not something to go under your radar. As you can expect, you plan as Van Helsing while also having with your ghost friend and companion Lady Katarina. The world from the game is a mix of wilderness in forests, swamps and secret lairs with a combination of cities inspired by the gothic architecture that blends perfectly with the theme of Van Helsing.

The Story is easy to follow and it is told in a very casual manner without taking itself too seriously by adding one little joke here and there. As you advance in your main story you will be asked to do another tasks, which, while entirely optional they are highly recommended to do since it will show you different enemies and different worlds. The best part of doing these side quests was that, not once I felt overwhelmed with a ridiculous amount of tasks to do, it’s just about the right amount of content if you just want to play a 20 hour long game without the need to grind by keep killing the same old monsters or soldiers over and over again.

With the option to choose between a more ranged or melee approach to kill your enemies, the variety in the customization is also a pleasant surprise. Depending on the style you choose how you want to engage your enemies you can engage them from far or close and personal so it’s really up to you how to tackle them. There’s also a decent selection of Auras, Skills and other powers and abilities for you to explore and learn as you level up. Lady Katarina, your companion, is also customizable and you can even order her on how to approach your enemies as well what to you want her to do. She can attack from close or long range, focus on the weakest enemies or on those harming you not to mention you can ask her to go sell your unwanted loot or even to buy some health and mana potions, saving plenty of time to explore a bit while she’s shopping for you.

It’s a very easy-to-follow game and fairly enjoyable. I never felt frustrated or bored and the game did not felt repetitive, something that may be common in these types of games. I had an enjoyable experience from start to finish while listening the pleasant soundtrack and the funny sayings from lady Katarina from time to time.

reviewText: Rating: 8/10\n\nThis game definitely belongs to the better half of the hack'n'slash RPG out there and has probably the best kind of humor amongst them all. Gameplay is really nice and smooth, with various skill tree (tricks/actives/passives/auras...) and many side-quests, hovewer, it's pretty short in comparison to other similar pieces. You can extend your game experience by playing single scenarious or start neverending story mode (something like NG+). If you decide to buy this game, I would recommend to get the DLC's as well, since they really add some nice features which original game lacks (new skill tree for Katarina, and most importantly, two new classes - Thaumaturge and Arcane Mechanic).

reviewText:
Maybe I haven't played enough of it, but I haven't been all that impressed by it. It's well executed for what it is, but it feels a bit like someone took Diablo and slapped a steampunk skin on it. Since I've never actually been a fan of Diablo-style RPGs, it's not my cup of tea. Of course, since Diablo isn't my thing, either, this may well be a better execution of that style, I just don't know. Since it's not my taste, I don't think it's fair to give it a negative review.  It's very pretty, and the monsters and worldbuilding are very good, I just can't get into it.

Edit 5/27/2015:
I went and tried it out again, hoping that some time and different perspective would change my opinion. It didn't. I just can't get into it. A whole lot of it feels grimdark for the sake of grimdark, and there seems to be very little story other than genocide as many monsters as you can."

reviewText:
One of those rare instances where the zerg rush has been perfected outside of an RTS. The first in a trilogy of games, Van Helsing's Hack and Slash adventure offers some surprisingly diverse game play, witty banter, teeth grinding moments, and an overall good experience in one package.

The game allows for easy switching between ranged and melee attacks. You're ghostly companion is also useful, as well as buffs you. The game itself is well done, with a pletora of items, stats, askills, and abilities to tweak to your hearts content. It also gives you the ability to adjust your stats and skills (for a price) so you don't have to worry about making a mistake in your build. The story is also interesting, with some good humour written into it.

The game itself is a little buggy. Music tends to dissapear at times, and the melee skill habitually dissapeared, very annoying during a fight. Even on normal, enemy density is quite large in some areas, resulting in the veritable zerg rush that can quickly get you killed if your not ready for it. While it does force you to put some thoughts into tactics, it can also be quite annoying at times (waaaaaay too much zerg on the last boss).

The other potential issue, is that the other two classes, and the ability to manually level your companion, have to be acquired via dlc.

Overall however, this was an excellent and enjoyable game that is worth trying if you are into diablo-esque games (though you may want to try and pick it up on sale so you can get the all the dlc at a good price). Looking forward to playing th next two parts in the series to see how the plot will thicken.

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is an ARPG. It's a very good, entertaining ARPG. I've had plenty of fun with the game, especially once the online was fixed and I picked up the Thaumaturge. The DLC classes are a bit pricey, especially since they add a bit of much-needed diversity to the game, but the base content is by no means bad. Just a bit limited in your character options, especially for more than 2-3 people.

The atmosphere and tone of the game is dark, but at the same time it's not. The dialouge is surprisingly entertaining, but not all that great. The back and forth with Katarina and the hunter is especially amusing. There are a few other humorous characters (like the priest in the village), but no one really THAT memorable.

The combat is pretty standard fare for the genre, but it's not bad, or even bland. I'm not a Diablo 2 veteran or anything, so I can't really say for sure how done-to-death" this whole system is
date: but I enjoyed it.\n\nIT"S a good game. If you like ARPGs
hoursPlayed: it's not a bad one to pick up. Especially if it's on sale. Like it is right now."

reviewText: I didn't enjoyed The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing more than any of Diablo games. But for some reason, it was more fun than Torchlight series. Why? Not sure. Maybe because it looks a little more dark and I really loved atmosphere in this game. Having a lovely companion also made me enjoy this game really much and the way you could spend her skill points in whatever way you want was a good idea - you can build her so she will be a real support for the way you will be playing, not some kind of obstacle.\nMaybe because I was focused on hand-to-hand combat, sometimes I really had hard times - every new area ended for me the same way, with more deads than I could count. Not that I hated it, maybe it was also my fault, but I enjoyed it. This way I had more fun than just running and killing everyone with 1 hit. Also, the boss fights are great.\nGraphics looks nice, music fits really well. I could only complaing about how game ends, and while the story isn't the best but not that it really matter, at least I look for something different in hack and slash games. If you are fan of those, if you look for something interesting in this genre - you should try The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing. Maybe it's no use comparing it to other games like that but for sure it's worth playing. It's game that grabbed my attention for few hours and the time I spend playing it was truly fun.

reviewText:
I really love ARPGs and the way they play, that said I absolutely despise this game.
I'm reccomending it because despite its major flaws it's still playable and has a great atmosphere, although you're very likely to get fed up with it and uninstall.

I'll start this off by saying that all of its problems are caused by too many enemies at once, this game goes completely overboard in that department.

Area of effect damage is a requirement, anything that does single target is next to useless here. The further you go into the game the larger the mob of enemies it constantly throws at you becomes, you can't even pick them off from a distance because chances are that the entire mob is going to react and come after you, and another thing to note is that your ranged attacks do not go over enemies which means all those high damage ranged enemies are safe behind the giant wall in your face. And on top of that some of them can heal other enemies, so you HAVE to kill them first.

There is a perk that makes you atheral when your health runs out, you're going to find yourself getting a lot of useage out of that one. Along with that you're going to find yourself needing to heal constantly, so cooldown reduction is an absolute must so you can use heal often.
I cannot even fathom playing the game class due the fact that there are enemies who drain your mana beyond faster than you can regenerate it even with mana potions, and this doesn't stop being a pain if with other classes, because all of your skills cost mana to use except your default skills.

reviewText: This game is indeed pretty incredible, both in its amount of bugs (many still being patched as of when I played through it, and the devs are very willing to patch in fixes to busted save files and such if you ask on their boards), and how fun it is. It's basically an indie Diablo clone, but focusing much more on story and banter between the main character and his ghostly companion than is typical for the genre. To some degree, it ended up reminding me more of Dragon Age than a normal action RPG.\n\nI really enjoyed my playthrough with Umbaglo and would highly recommend this to anyone who likes action RPGs and is willing to put up with its slightly wonky design and the mass of hilarious bugs it suffers from. It's not super long (15-20 hours) and not as focused on playing through the same content 3+ times as many action RPGs, as well, so it's also not a huge expenditure of time to play through, while still being a satisfying length.

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing from developer NeocoreGames is a action role-playing game, in the vein of the Diablo series. While the title's price would suggest it might be a bargain bin title, the actual truth is far different as the game contains an extensive amount of content that is polished and entertaining. While the game's scope might not be as large as other titles in the genre, the content easily consumes hours upon hours of time as gaining new loot and slaying monsters of all sorts is an addictive experience.
The game's narrative has players partaking on a journey as the son of famous monster slayer Van Helsing along with a ghost companion named Lady Katarina.  Together you will explore  various locales in the gothic and magic-infused kingdom of Borgovia. Settings range from forests crawling with werewolves to dark city streets controlled by mechanized armies of soldiers. Each chapter provides the player with a hub base or town to buy and sell supplies as well as plenty of quests that require the aid of a monster slayer. While some quests incorporate puzzles and even tower defense elements, the majority of objectives have players slaying endless amounts of monsters.
Much of the narrative's enjoyment can be contributed to the great dialogue exchanges between Helsing and Lady Katarina. One-liners and an assortment of sarcastic comments from each make both of them lovable characters throughout the game's narrative. It's not often in action role-playing games such as Diablo or Torchlight that the player's character has much of a personality other than their style in battle. It's a refreshing change that not just the main characters have great personalities in the game, but also much of the characters that players meet in the game's world.
Veterans of the genre will immediately feel at home as standard mechanics for the genre are all in place. As you would expect players earn experience from slaying enemies and completing quests for use in upgrading their character's assortment of skills. The skill system is split into melee combat, ranged combat, and magical abilities, each of which contain both active and passive skills that can be leveled. Lady Katarina also contains her own assortment of skills that not only strengthen her combat and defense, but also abilities that aid Helsing both inside and outside of battles.
Aside from completing a near endless amount of quests, players can spend their time crafting better weapons and equipment as well as upgrading their base's defenses in the game's later stages. As Helsing's role is a monster slayer, he is skilled in both melee and ranged combat enabling him to switch instantly between a sword and rifle or pistols.
As with most action role-playing games, the major draw of battling enemies and completing quests is the drive to acquire more loot. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing delivers up to a degree as the game contains a wide assortment of weapons and gear to loot from fallen monsters. The one lacking area with the loot system is limited customization of the protagonist's appearance as most armor and clothing items differ only slightly from each other.
The game doesn't disappoint with its visuals as all of the elements ranging from environments to monsters are both highly-detailed and polished. The variety of monsters remain satisfying through the narrative's course with players confronting enemies from werewolves to magical-based, mechanized soldiers.
While the sound effects from exploding enemies to the howls of werewolves aren't anything special, the game's soundtrack sets the tone perfectly with an assortment of memorable tracks. The soundtrack works especially well with various environments in the game's world, which results in the perfect atmosphere for slaying monsters and collecting loot.
It's not often that games are released containing such an extensive amount of content in addition to being highly-polished for such a low price. The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing offers players both a satisfying and addictive experience over the course of its lengthy adventure. . The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a must-buy for fans of slaying monsters and acquiring masses of loot.

reviewText:
I adore this style of gaming and the fantasy theme calls to something within me. So when the game on sale I quickly clicked 'buy' and began my quest as a Van Helsing. So, what did I think (and still do as I have by no means completed it)?

I FREAKING LOVE this game! The theme and back-drop to the game is spot on as you wade through hordes of all varieties of mythical monstrosities.  Graphically, the game delivers well and is pleasing to the eye. The voice acting for Van Helsing and Katarina (DLC) is superb. Really well done! The banter between them adds depth to their characters and is a real treat to hear. The musical score/sound effects are brilliant too and again adds to the immersion.
Character customisation is varied and gives much choice to the three classes to choose from. Each gives a different way of combating the horrors that await.
Loot... oh the loot. Much is to be gathered and acquired as one would expect from a game such as this. The game is fun to play, even more so with friends (or my dad in my case) but beware, the game (for me) can get addictive. I always feel I need to keep playing just to get that next item that will boost my DPS or to see what new enemies are lurking around the corner.

For all its pros there are unfortunately some cons. Certain shrines cannot be activated, instead once clicked causes your character to wander trying to find it even though it's right in front of them, denying you an XP/DMG boost. With the Arcane Mechanic class (which I play and love burning monsters with) when I click over an enemy to attack, he wonders off, not knowing where it is. A pathing issue with this and the shrines I'm thinking.
The worst issue (for me) is no matter how long I play for, be it five minutes or five hours, upon exiting the game my PC shows a CPU temperature warning. My PC is not old and boasts some high-end hardware so I was quite surprised when the message popped up. Never before have I seen such a message other than playing Skyrim (with mods and graphical enhancements) for almost an entire day straight, which is justified. These issues I have are not enough for me to stop playing, but it would be nice if they were resolved.

9/10

reviewText:
Van Helsing is a stellar representative of the action-RPG genre. Katarina, your constant ghostly companion, is a witty follower you'll be glad to have at your side. She functions very much like Torchlight's pets, and she and Van Helsing engage in frequent, humourous banter. There's a large world to explore which sports a rather steampunk flair, and it overflows with an equally large roster of enemies which take cues from popular fantasy villains, all with a mechanical overlay. (Electric werewolves, anyone?)

One of my favorite features that made late gameplay much easier was the ability to reset skill and ability points for both yourself and Katarina. This allows you to readjust your stats for how you've developed your play style. Because I never focused on ranged combat, removing nearly all my points in that ability and pumping up my melee attack made what had become frustrating game time a pleasure again.

Unfortunately, most equipment largely looks the same, so your character never appears visually as epic as Torchlight characters. A few times gameplay feels unessessarily stretched with a similar mission repeated or a mandatory replay of an already-cleared area.

These litle grieveances aside, Van Helsing is a surprisingly great game. Fans of Diablo and Torchlight need look no further for their next fix.

reviewText: After finishing Torchlight 2 I wanted to play something that looks alike. Finally, I got this game at sale with some friends of mine. At first sight everything seemed to be great: lots of skills and branches, very helpful assistant Catherine that can also level-up and has different builds. The first negative impression came on the first location after the town. My friend couldn’t load. After several changes of lobby leader and re-launching the game, the problem was solved. Ok, sh*t happens, nevermind. After a few hours one of  the characters reached 12 lvl and 99% and then stopped gaining any experience. After re-launching the game its level was 12 and 50%. Okaaay, let’s go forward. We all were 13 lvl, killed a boss on the quest location and…a miracle! Two characters stayed lvl 13 and the third one became lvl 5! He got 21 skill point and was unable to put on any clothes above his 5th lvl. This time re-launching didn’t help us at all, so after this I’ve lost any wish to continue playing this “fascinating” masterpiece. We’ll see what developers got at The incredible adventures of Van Helsing Final Cut.

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is a Hack 'N' Slay RPG.

You are Van Helsing, a monster hunter.
On your site is a hot evil ghost called Katarina.
You traveled into a region called Borgova.
Something evil is happening there and you have to find out what it is.
Your way leads you through cities, forests, caves and many more things just to find the person who is responsible for everything.

The gameplay is nice. Its like other Hack 'N' Slays like Diablo or Torchlight but it has a dark steampunk touch.
I really like the whole design of the game, beats Diablo and Torchlight in my opinion.
There is an incredible amount of weapons and accessoires.
The game has a typical level up system which gives you skillpoints everytime you level up.
Some items are also only usable when having a certain level.
Furthermore there are bonuses for finishing certain quests like killing 100 werewolves or whatever.
You can choose some bonuses from time to time.
Nearly everything is also supported by Katarina.
The enemy varity is pretty much actually.
There are several groups of enemies and those have always different levels.
Masters are the most dangerous. There are also veterans and others.
Also there are some bosses ingame.
People in the world might give you quests from time to time, nothing special but gives you a lot of loot.
Loot is the best about this game anyway. Its addicting collecting loot.
The difficult is higher than usual I think, at least I died several times even with using healing mage and a lot of potions.
I played on Normal. I personally skilled myself on far fight. Isnt easy though because the monster approach you very fast.

The Graphics are good for a game of that sort, nothing special though.
But I really liked the whole design especially of the forest.
It will also run on older PCs.

I also have to say that the music of the game is really nice.
I read that there is a soundtrack avaiable, but only for the second game.
Should include the music from the first game too, I read.

The game also has some sort of Multiplayer, didnt looked into it until now though.
It has Coop which is nice, I will probably try it sometime.

I have to say that I didnt awaited a lot of this game but I really started to love it.
Its addicting and has a interesting story and design.
Definitely a good game for Hack 'N' Slay fans.
I will probably buy the second game earlier or later.
I will give the game 8/10 points.

reviewText:
IAVH is a fun, solid game with a few problems that keeps it from rising above a 8/10.

The Good:

Now with 3 character classes, you are no longer stuck with one guy that does everything half-♥♥♥♥♥. Classes are still rather plain being the melee, magic and ranged stereotypes. The skills the classes feature are mostly unique, with a small selection of them being repeats of skills other classes have.
The perk system is fun and adds a unique feel to your character. Katarina the ghost WAS a ♥♥♥♥-poor addition. With all the patches and full dlc I feel she is actually worth putting into combat now. Having her tank damage and aggro for me has been rather effective, rather than before when she was dying in 5 hits while being built tanky. Loot drop rate is still really high, but the loot is much better and I find myself playing just to find the next drop. I've not used the glory system yet but it looks like a decent way to keep higher levels interested in their build.

The Bad:

Multiplayer community is tiny. You will rarely see more than 25 games during peak time, and as little as none during others. Rarely will the games be hosted in the US region. What this means is basically if you're in the US, you need friends to play this game with. Relying on random people from the internet is merely not enough. If you can get past the glaring lag, there's still many more issues that need to be addressed. As such, I can only recommend that if you pickup IAVH for the multiplayer, get your friends to do so as well, or don't get it at all. There are also technical problems with the graphical engine. Running IAVH on full settings produces BSOD extremely often. Although entirely capable of running the game maxed, I can't because of blue screens. Games released both before and after have no problem being maxed without technical problems. This is something that can be fixed, but there's no guarantee that it will be.

Ultimately, I enjoy the game and I think you would too. If you must have multiplayer, but do not have any PC gaming buddies to play with, I'd pass over this one, random internet denizens will just not be enough.

reviewText:
(Do note I haven't played online) This game is great, plenty of loot, abilities, fun skills, controls and interface is solid, and game can be challenging at times. Before I go into what i didn't like and the final anwser i'll talk about all the positive things. They added variety to the game with the multiple classes and the extendtion for your companions skills, the areas look detailed and urges you to explore. You can build your character in multiple ways because of the way the skill tree is, so You have a melee section, ranged section, tricks and auras as you move further down the techtree it costs more to level the abilities which means you cant just get everything. You have to plan out what kind of character you want to make allowing you to be different from other players characters. This also adds to the replayability to try new combos.

After you beat the game you can play 2 other modes that extend the lifespan of a single character, trying to make them the perfect hunter, by playing these gamemodes you get to find better loot and get points to further increase their stats. The max level is 30, I use to think this was bad but as I played it fit perfectly for the content available and with the glory point system in the other game modes you can still make them better.

The puzzles and side quests are also a lot of fun since it keeps things interesting.
The powerup abilities for your skills also adds depth to how you use your abilities.

Now for some negetive points, once in awhile buildings got in my way from seeing what was happening (they wouldn't go transparent) though this was only in a few places it still should happen. Some of the enemy champions (elites) have unfair abilities, the wall is fine since you can shoot it, the drain is fine since you can run away from it, most of them are fine except for 2, grapple is annoying and unfair, it grabs you from so far away, cant be dodged (haven't seen it miss), it stuns you as it pulls you to them, they can all cast it sametime increasing the stun effect. It has gotten me killed on multiple accounts. the other is the skeleton hand that cages you, you have to attack the hand to break free however you cant move and it works the same way as the grapple, it doesn't miss (haven't seen it miss) but these are from my experience there might be a way.

The lack of map variety, to what I see the maps are static, not randomized each time.

The game has some strange difficulty spikes, one moment its simple and easy, next moment you are running spamming pots cause the mobs are no joke anymore but overall it doesn't happen often.

If you accidently forget to complete a quest, the journal doesn't tell you which area the quest is for, so you have to do quite a bit of backtracking to find out which can be a pain.

Loading screens, it's not that bad but it would be nice if it was faster, it intrupts the flow of the game.

The music is good and the sound effects are pleasing. The graphics are great and the game runs very smooth. The variety of loot, enchanting, using essences, the dialogue, voice acting are all good. the game was lots of fun to play and got my monies worth.

I give the game a 8.5/10 for being what its suppose to be, to offer some unique features and have a good pace. But for the lack of replayability because of repeating exactly what you did before and the loading screens with not that great backtracking method, no randomized maps and some inconsistency. It's worth buying and offers enough and some for what you pay for.

reviewText: The Incredible Adventures берет другим — подачей и оформлением. Охотник за нечистью очень приятно и литературно выражается, идеально сохраняя образ; его подруга каждые 15 минут выдает остроты; окружающие персонажи продуманы и прописаны настолько, чтобы каждая из отведенных им фраз звучала свежо и интересно. В этом смысле игру хочется сравнить, наверное, с Magicka — все не настолько абсурдно, но настолько же талантливо.\n\nОтличные диалоги накладываются на постоянное обновление места действия — каждые пару часов стиль игры радикально преображается. Просторные полянки сменяются многоуровневыми улочками, классические злые вороны вытесняются изощренными франкенштейнами, а сопровождается это обновлением цветовой гаммы и музыкальной темы. Саундтрек вообще хочется выделить отдельно — очень уж он приятен для малобюджетного проекта.

reviewText:
Van Helsing is definately not a game without flaws, but for the most part they all seem to have counterpoints.  The lack of meaningful character customization is off-set by the tightly focused story-driven nature of the game.  The static maps kill replayability a bit, but also allow for better designed set pieces.

The skill system is a shallow ocean- giving the illusion of depth but in order to be viable you really need to pick a set of a couple skills and pour all your points into them. I can't speak for the ranged tree as I primarily played melee, your choices are somewhat limited given the crazy mob density that this game throws at you- which, don't get me wrong, was definately a positive- but it means that you need abilities that will kill a lot of guys at once in order to keep from being overwhelmed or whittling guys down at a choke point one at a time for hours on end. Then, while you're doing that you realize you could just be Earthquaking all the guys in a row and be done 10 times quicker.

In short, Van Helsing is worth the price of admission, especially if you can catch it on sale.  It's a fun, short romp that does what it advertises, just don't expect a Diablo/Torchlight/Path of Exile killer.

reviewText:
Let me start by saying I haven't beaten this game yet, but at level 26, I'm far enough in to give a review. I'm going to list pros and cons and then expand upon them down below. I'm not really going to touch upon the story all that much.

Pros:

Story is alright (nothing special, but it's better than most of what you'll find these days)
Nice level design
Game provides a challenge (both a pro and a con, see below)
Katarina is a pretty cool character
Varied enemies

Cons:

Framerate tanks to below 30 in some areas if you can believe that
AI partner is useless
Game provides a challenge (both a pro and a con, see below)
Very lame skilltree as a mage
Voice acting is pretty lame (Van Helsing isn't too bad, Katarina is hit or miss and the rest of the NPC's are pretty bad)
Combat is boring

To start off, you play as Van Helsing's son (yea, THE Van Helsing). Something is wrong in this city that your father cleared out years ago and you must save the day. You are accompanied by Katarina, a ghost who is bound to serve your family. She is your partner in combat and can either be a melee or ranged specialist. She also levels up and has her own skill tree.

This game does a few things right. Level design is something you will notice upon loading up a new area. The areas you prod around in are generally large and look pretty good. So far I've been through a small village, forested areas, a mine, a sewer, secret laboratories, The Ink (kind of a take on The Fade from Dragon Age) and a big city. Each location has impressed me thus far. Also a plus is Katarina herself. Trudging around the game by yourself would get pretty boring. Her presence, combined with the banter she has with Van Helsing is decent enough to where the game doesn't feel so grindy. Also a plus are the various types of enemies with different abilities. The game groups up different enemies constantly, and some of the battles can be very tough.

Unfortunately, for every thing this game does right, there's two things it does wrong. Firstly, the game tanks to below 30 FPS in certain areas. This is on a 4770k with 2x 7870 Myst Editions. It's happened in two areas so far. It's not in one little spot on the map, either. The framerate keeps tanking throughout the whole area. If I leave the area, I start getting great frames again. As soon as I go back in, it tanks again. I guess those areas were just very poorly optimized. Next, combat is weak at best. I am playing as a mage, and combat doesn't feel good at all. None of the spells you can unlock feel good/forceful, and some of them require you to keep clicking your mouse button to charge up a spell, draw a line on the screen for a wall of fire, etc. This wouldn't be such a problem if you weren't fighting 20+ enemies at a time, and if your AI partner was competent. Katarina is utterly useless. I thought setting her up as a melee specialist would let her tank damage and draw enemy aggro as I hit them from range with my spells. Not quite. Enemies run right by her as if she's not even there and book it straight at me. This leads to every battle turning into a StraCraft-esque kite-fest, which gets old, fast. To make matters worse, you cannot command Katarina to attack a target. You can setup behaviors for her where she'll attack your target, the weakest target, the most vulnerable target, or the target that is attacking you (which is all of them), but you can't click on a target for her to attack. This means you have to aggro the enemies yourself. Not a problem if you're playing a sword-wielding badass, but as a mage it's terrible.

As I mentioned the game provides a challenge. Some of that is due to good enemy design, but most of it is artificial. Katarina being terrible and enemies running straight for you are the two biggest culprits of that artificial difficulty. Also contributing to this are some of the enemy groups you will run into. For instance, there is a part in a laboratory where you run into 6-7 Champion versions (the enemies have different tiers, Champion being the toughest) of this one enemy that has the ability to raise undead, trap you temporarily, form a temporary barrier, lay down an AOE poison spell, and an AOE spell that just drains your health as soon as you step into it. The fight went something like this. Step into area, trigger aggro on the 6-7 enemies, they cast raise undead to the 50+ rat-like corpses on the ground, use barrier so I can't go anywhere, use trap to hold me in place, cast poison or the other AOE spell on me while the rat things beat on me and I'm dead in seconds. I died 10+ times in that one place, due solely to how cheap the enemies were. This type of nonsense happens every now and again.

When it comes down to it, I can't recommend this game. If only the combat matched the pretty visuals...

reviewText:
It is a generic version of Diablo 3, but fun, although a bit repetative. Great graphics, but the sound is oddly low. Great music. The problem is that unlike the other 105 games I have installed, it heats up my system big time, making the fan on my gpu go nuts after about an hour of play. Hotter than even a huge multiplayer game in BF4. And it's a GTX680, so that should never happen. I chalk it up to poor programming and it is no surprise since this game is very obviously not a AAA game.

It is a very fun game, but only in short bursts. It gets very, very repetative quickly. Do not expect much when buying games that are cheap, do not expect much from this. However it is not a bad game and I have fun with it from time to time.

6.5/10
