reviewText:
Enjoyable action RPG with many of the same features you would find in Diablo style games.  If you're looking for a good single player story, character customization options, and all around monster slaughtering goodness then this won't disappoint.

I suggest getting the full pack that includes all of the DLC as it opens up a number of new classes, features for all of the classes, some new quests/areas, and equipment.

If you've enjoyed Diablo, Diablo 2, Diablo 3, Path of Exile, or any of the other similar ARPG's this is a good one for you!

Note, this is not a strong multiplayer game or something you can expect to invest a lot of time into.  You'll enjoy the story, level a character or two, and then be done with it forever.

reviewText:
Solid Action RPG with a lot of heart & wit.

Pros:  Atmospheric, enthrallling art direction.    Banter between Van Helsing & his Wraith companion is snappy & lively.    Dialogue for other NPCs is also stellar.   Animations are spiffy.    Creature design is spot on.    Varied levels keep the gameplay fresh.     The Dev tried a lot of different things & succeeded for the most part.

Cons:   Ending is a little disjointed.    Closing cinematic & on screen action don't exactly jive.    Crafting system isn't well explained.     Still, it's quite entertaining taken as a whole.

Bring on the Sequel!!!

reviewText:
Pros:
- cheap
- simple
- sometimes looks okay
- setting not entirely cloned from Diablo series

Cons:
- ♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice acting
- 20GB for barely anything
- you can lag as the host
- crashes sometimes
- items seem hardly relevant, skills are 99% of the damage
- characters' looks hardly ever change by more than just tiny bits
- terrible pathfinding and level design from hell
- large portions of the game (2/3 classes...) only in a DLC
- no difficulty scaling. You can play on casual and still get onehits throughout the game, but most of the time you just hold RMB and wait til it's over.

It's an okay-ish game in its price range that would have needed some polishing. It looks mostly budget or dated, but still takes a lot more performance than what you get for in return. Could have been more.

reviewText:
Van Helsing gets a couple of things right: the atmosphere is great, the graphics look pretty good and remind me of Diablo 2. Having a companion who is always cracking jokes, usually at your expense is also entertaining, I thought the voice acting was done quite well.

As an ARPG though, this game is a disapointment. The main campain is rather short, you can easily finish it in 10 hours. Unlike other ARPG's, there is no grinding for better items or skills since there are no areas where enemies respawn and you will have visited almost every part of every area once you finish the game the first time. There is no reason to revisit it since there is no new game+ either.

The one aspect of the game that really interested me was the tower defense element. Unfortunately this is also a disappointment as it does not fit into the story well and seems more tacked on, not only that but there are only two short tower defense parts in the whole game and no way to do any optional missions at all.

Multiplayer doesn't work well, I've read many reports of people experiencing bugs and I also had a couple of problems when I tried it, quests getting stuck and similar problems. Another problem is that when a person in your party starts a bug you are forced to join after 5 seconds, even if you are in a dialogue with an NPC.

reviewText:
If you really enjoyed Diablo or those type of games, it's worth checking this game out. The developers obviously cared about their finished product.

If you're on the fence or you do not enjoy those games, do not try this. The first half of the game is pretty enjoyable, but after a while you either get so specialized and good with your skills that you are ripping stuff apart or it just feels downright repetitive, although that may just be a hallmark of this type of game's combat system.

It's about 15 hours long, give or take a few hours depending on how quickly you move through it and how thorough you are. I played the entire game single player, so perhaps multiplayer is a completely different experience. If you plan on playing this alone though, unless you're really in love with this type of game, do not purchase it.

reviewText:
SNAPSHOT
An uninspired Diablo clone that does more wrong than it does right. I wish I had more to say here.

OVERALL - 4.5 / 10

PROS
+ art is actually pretty good

CONS
- extremely clunky movement / combat
- ability point buy / upgrade system is extremely boring and lackluster
- story and dialogue are cringe-worthy
- lots of loading
- $4 DLC single talent trees

DETAILS
While I really wanted to like this game, overall it just falls flat in all regards. From the beginning, Van Helsing has been fraught with bugs and a lack of anything going right. To start, multiplayer was completely inaccessible for the first 6-7 months after release, and many quests were bugged such that they could not be completed. Releasing an extremely buggy game: strike #1.

Supposedly a lot of bugs have been fixed in the past 6 months, but this game was purchased specifically to play multiplayer at release and months went by with other (seemingly less important) bugs being fixed, and multiplayer is still not one of them. I have seen multiple instances of it being marked fixed" in patch notes
date: only to find it is still as buggy as ever. Even without multiplayer
recommended: there are still a LOT of bugs that are easily found that stick out like sore thumbs. On top of this fact
hoursPlayed: DLC was apparently being worked on for the game starting after it was released
voteText: using vital manpower that should have been used to fix bugs to instead leave people that bought the game out in the cold. Focusing on future profits instead of fixing buggy products for current customers: strike #2.\n\nTurns out that all of the DLC (at this writing) just adds single talent trees to Van Helsing or the companion

reviewText:
PROS:
*Looks nice enough
*Choice of swordsman, gunslinger, or mage for the original character; choice of mage or engineer with DLC
*Unique helper who can be a melee or ranged fighter, buy and sell items for the player while he's in the field, and be customized to behave as the player wishes
*Adequate number of quests
*Respawning monsters can be turned on or off
*Scenarios and Neverending Story provide some replayability after completing the game
*Co-op with a fair loot system
*Skill and stat reset and unlockable perks
*Little to no need to grind
*Changes in weapons and armor actually affect character appearance, though the character's size makes these changes minor

CONS:
*Repetitive gameplay
*Visually unimpressive skills
*Glitches
*Slow response to glitches (newer games seem to take priority)
*Uninspired story
*Tedious tower defense section
*Little incentive to play the additional modes
*Considerable lag on even the lowest settings in some areas during co-op if one's computer doesn't meet the recommended specifications
*20 GB download with little to show for it

???:
*Fury system

GAME LENGTH:
Those who just want to complete the game on normal difficulty at a normal pace should expect to take 12-15 hours.  Achievement hunters will take varying amounts of time depending on what difficulty they choose at the start and whether or not they select hardcore mode, but should be aware that several achievements involve a great deal of grinding.  I took around 30 hours to get all of the achievements besides those related to hardcore mode and difficulty and those involving the greatest amount of grinding.

SCORE:
5 out of 10

I happened to start playing this after an update that broke a few aspects of the game.  It took too long for the developers to address these issues and, even when they did, some remained.  For example, the Thaumaturge's blizzard skill is supposed to do a certain amount of damage in a small visible area on the screen, but instead causes massive (fatal) damage to all enemies within 2 screens of the player.  This can easily be abused to make every area and boss a joke.  I also found myself unable to complete a main quest because of a bug that prevents a quest item spawn, yet the only fix available is to actually type a command into the game.  The game has been out since May 2013 and the developers have gone on to make Van Helsing II, Van Helsing III, and a spin-off of the tower defense element of the game.  At this point, there is no excuse for persistent bugs and lazy fixes.

Still, if these bugs were my only problem with the game, I would recommend it.  The trouble is that it's not particularly fun.

Gameplay consists of running from one mob of enemies to the next, using the same two or three skills again and again.  The game does feature a unique mechanic called Fury, which is gained by attacking enemies and spent to give skills unique buffs if the player has spent skill points on those buffs.  For example:  if the player uses skill points to unlock the flamethrower skill and additional skill points to unlock one of its 3-5 buffs, flamethrower might do 50% more damage or cause persistent fire damage to enemies if the buff is invoked.  However, the buff is also spent upon activation, meaning fury must be used to ready it again for any subsequent attack.  I found the system rather awkward to use because of all of the key presses involved, but others might enjoy it, so I list it neither as a pro nor a con.  In any case, it didn't change the nature or feel of the gameplay for me.

The three unique bosses (one for the end of each act) offer something different, but only because the player has to first run around activating towers, completing a tower defense section, or destroying spawners first to have a good chance of killing them.  The developers apparently thought that the tower defense section of the second act was good enough to turn into a stand-alone game (Death Trap), but to me it seemed to drag on for too long.  It is like Orcs Must Die! (one of my favorite games) in the sense that the player places traps on tiles and is free to assist his traps in killing enemies, who can also target him.  However, the player must gather materials to place traps and also has a limit on how many can be placed.  The trap variety is decent, at least for what amounts to a mini-game, but in the interest of achievement hunting, I followed others' advice and used just one kind of trap:  the werewolf cage.  Perhaps the experience would have been more enjoyable if I had been more adventurous, but I doubt it.  The length of this section and the constant micromanagement with the player character, which I enjoyed in Orcs Must Die! but disliked here, just sapped any fun out of it.  And then I had to do it again for another quest.

The story is arguably the biggest disappointment, as it merely amounts to a hunt for a one-dimensional villain who is out to hurt people.  There is no depth, minimal world-building, and no incentive to play apart from an interest in getting better weapons and putting points into skills, neither of which conveyed much of a sense of progression.  The player only gets enough points to max out a handful of skills, most of which both look and feel unimpressive, and the weapons all handle about the same way, with minimal boosts to damage as the player progresses.

The cooperative aspect of the game was the biggest draw for me since I have a wife who occasionally likes to play.  Our first problem was getting the game to work:  even though her computer surpasses the minimum requirements and mine surpasses the recommended, we both got stuck on an endless initial loading screen.  Eventually I got it working, but it wasn't long before the next problem.  When we reached the second large map (Gallowsbog), the game lagged too much even on the lowest settings for her to be able to do anything at all.  I was forced to play the rest of the game on my own, without company to distract me from the game's other failures.

After finishing the game, I had little interest in buying the next in the series.  After reading some of the reviews and glitch reports for both sequels, I lost what little interest I had left.

For the tedious gameplay, poor optimization, unimpressive skills, and bugs that remain unfixed to this day, I give this game a 5 out of 10.

reviewText: Good for hours of playtime, but not much else.  The storyline is forgettable, the voice-acting is okay, and the visuals are pretty decent for this style of game.  However, you will die multiple times even on normal, due to the fact that most enemies will simply swarm your character.  Even after lowering the graphics settings, my computer would lag to the point where it simply wouldn't register button presses, hence my character wouldn't use a crucial potion and died.  And died.  After beating the campaign you have the option to complete scenarios (aka, recycled levels from the game) to level up or start a new game with the same character.  I tried the latter and made it a short way into the story before giving up, as the difficulty is much greater on the new game plus.

reviewText:
If you are someone who plays games on a MAC, do not even bother buying this game. It should not be advertised as a MAC compatible game! Neocore has known about the problems concerning this game for years yet they refuse to fix them. The game looks terrible and is prone to frequent crashing.

When changing the settings it is near impossible to see the change. The game will constantly be pixelated regardless of how you change the settings. Along with the blurry images which can be dealt with, the text size is so tiny that it is required for the player to either squint to make out what is being said or turn down the resolution, and even then the situation is barely improved.

If you are looking for a new game to play on MAC, you are better off buying diablo, which is ported at a much better quality. The lack of support and seeming care of the development team is obvious. This game is not worth the money and time. I really wanted to enjoy this game but the blantent lack of care has lead me to have a distaste for this game. Van Helsing 2 also suffers from this lack of support, adopting all the problems from this game.

Save your money.
Don't buy this game.

reviewText:
Surprisingly motivating, considering it's just a hack&shoot. Maybe it's the actual existence of a somewhat interesting story, maybe the tons of achievements.
The character customization is interesting, too, though.
You can choose whether to have respawning mobs or not for single player story.
There are weapons that grow more powerful with use and stuff is sharable between your chars.
There is some interesting variety in gameplay to shake up the relatively dull hack&shoot a bit.
I play it on easy and it's still enjoyable.

I got the game in a bundle though, not because I deliberately wanted to have it. Since Valve doesn't allow neutral reviews and I'm focusing on a certain downside that might be of interest to some people, I'll give this a negative one. (Really can't decide.)

The amount of loot that drops in this game borders on trolling. There's too damn much loot, and the stats compare is a pain, not only because you have to do it for two characters, but because it's confusing and unreliable. A lot of the gametime tends to be about sorting out items.

I think I'm only managing to keep playing it because of the achievements.

(The game has a demo, so the rest you can derive from that.)


- Terrain scrolling is far from being smooth. Considering the visual quality and my system, it's a bit sad. Fog even causes extreme framerate drops. This engine seems unoptimized.

- Fakenook, Twitter and Youtube links on the main screen, hurting immersion. This is about as annoying as Youtubers saying like
recommended:
favorite and subscribe" all the time.

- And now the big issue right at the beginning:
Rarely does a game bombard a personal firewall as much as this. It tries to connect to api.parse.com and amazonaws.com and oftentimes every half a second to mail.neocoregames.com (even after startup - it basically bombards your firewall permanently) and if you don't allow this stuff
hoursPlayed: then the game will freeze for several minutes before you even see the main menu.\nThis is with a set block rule

reviewText:
It reminds me Diablo III which I play a lot.  It has LOT of similarities.
Except it LACKs MAC optimisation.
I have MacBook Pro (Retina, 15-inch, Mid 2014) with Intel Iris Pro 1536 MB (HD 5200)

Diablo III runs at 1080p at 40fps using HIGH details.
VH 1 runs (shutters) at 720p at 25fps using VERY LOW details. I tried V-sync, but then the game is VERY slow...

reviewText:
I'm on the fence about recommending this game, as it does have its fun points.  If the game wasn't so riddled with bugs it would be a fun enough, controller driven, Diablo light.

A decent game that is severely marred by bugs, and one of the worst inventory management schemes I think I've ever had to use.

If you like ARPGs, you may still enjoy this game if you can get it cheap enough.  Being able to play an ARPG on the PC with a controller is the big draw to this game, at least for me.

Be warned, there are some potentially game stopping bugs in the critical path.  There do seem to be various work arounds for many of these, but it's a bit of a crap shoot.

reviewText:
Hunter is a decent class to play, but early on, the Thaumaturge, even on normal, is really boring, and difficult.. Slow single target spell casts, fighting packs of 5+ enemies.. The main attack can take 3 to 5 hits to kill each enemy..

The hunter on the other hand, has the ability to melee, or range.. Default melee swings, or gun shots..

I enjoyed the game playing as the Van Helsing iconic class (Hunter), but really dislike how the Thaumaturge (spell caster) plays..

That said, Part 2 is FAR better than TAoVH1...

Is really badly optimized.. Im far above recommended specs, and the game gets below 20fps often.. Skimming through the discussions, theres dozens of people asking for help with the same issue..It really pisses me off that i have to turn off all the deent settings to play this game, which isnt really great looking to begin with..

All in all, i would say pass on it, unless you are a di hard arpg fan, and absolutely need another title... Because theres not enough of them apparently, lol..  Poor performance is the killer here..

reviewText: Tried this on my Macbook. Latest drivers, latest OS, latest patch (Feb 14 2014.) The character configuration screen is illegible and unusable, missing images and with text and mouseovers all over the place.\nThat alone wouldn't make me sad; I like supporting indy developers and understand there may be some debugging involved. But then I tried to join their forums to report the problem, and the enrollment didn't work. When I eventually mailed them (with screenshots, diagnostics, etc.) I got one answer telling me to update my drivers, and then they went dark. Not cool.\nI guess I'll be reclaiming some much-needed hard drive space.

reviewText: The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing looks like a great game. I was very excited to try this, and when it came up in the recent holiday sale, I nabbed it. Before buying, I verified that the game supports Mac and controllers. These top down games are some of my favorites, and I prefer the game controller to mouse and keyboard for them. Unfortunately, it seems that Mac is supported and controller is supported, but the two together are not supported. So I have not been able to play. I gave them almost four months to patch this issue, but, while other updates have been coming out, no fix for controllers on Macs has been seen. I won't buy another NeoCore game. I find their practices deceptive.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, I really did.

Positive:
-Small development team, who made a playable (not really enjoyable) game. It's always nice to see little dev teams making games.
-The starting price of $15 doesn't leave a bad taste in your mouth.
-Clever take on Van Helsing, with some cool concepts.
-I was expecting a pure text based game, with no voicework, yet I found the voicework to be better than some AAA games being released these days.
-It's short and doesn't overstay it's welcome.
-Decent replayability

Negative:
-The loading times are awful, they might be the worst loading times I've ever experienced in a game. There's also no loading indicator until 10 seconds prior to the next area loads up. So you're stuck looking at a boring map for 1-2 minutes, wondering if the game crashed.
-This games default settings are ridiculous and slow down the game (newsflash the majority of PC gamers don't have crossfire video cards).
-I found a few work arounds to speed up the load times to about 35-45 seconds but even then this game felt poorly optimized.
-I have a pretty decent rig that can still play Far Cry 3, Skyrim, and Deus EX on high, with my frame rate rarely dropping below 35-45 fps. So why the hell can this game barely stutter by at 5 fps?? I haven't seen a game stutter and drop the framerate this much since my '07 gateway when I played WoW.
-Oddly enough, I did find the frame rate to improve if I turned certain specs up not down (seriously).
-The enviroments are generic, the same old muddy sewers/forest/foggy forest/cave, you've seen a million times in generic RPGs.
-This game takes little to no strategy, I rarely died. When I did die, it was usually do to the screen stuttering and having my character jump across  the scene do to lag or a screen freeze.
-The character models are pretty dull, you fight the same spiders/rats/zombies from every RPG. Although they do have some cool looking revolutionary robot soldiers and Van Helsing himself looks alright, even if he is a walking cliché.
-Also for some reason the audio cuts in and out.
-Gameplay is weird, they try to be so different from Diablo/Torchlight, that they remap certain keys and get rid of others altogether. All I wanted was another hack'n'slash diabloesque RPG, yet this game tries to reinvent the wheel and ends up making a square tire.

Bottomline: This game is only worth picking up if it's part of some Humble Bundle or under $2. The forgettable story, boring graphics, frame rate issues, and loading screens will have you uninstalling this monster in less time then it takes to watch a trailer for that lame Van Helsing movie starring Wolverine.

1/5

reviewText:
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing played like any other hack and slash game on the market.  Really nothing new about it.  The game play and progression trees are both just fine.  The story was fairly interesting but again nothing really remarkable.  I enjoyed my first few hours of gameplay but became somewhat bored with the game and set it aside for awhile.  Recently I returned to the game in the hopes of finishing the story and being able to get a full impression of it.  Alas, it was not to be...

This game quickly shows it's true colors if you visit the forums for the game.  Many of the quests are broken and need to be reset using console commands to complete them.  This is just lazy on the part of the Dev. team who created a sequel and couldn't be bothered to fix the first one.  You'll also find many people have had problems getting the game to even launch...anyway from my personal experience the game will no longer resume story when I click resume story" just a wonderful crash to desktop.  After spending a few hours verifying the game cache on steam and even going as far as reinstalling the game and following all steps mentioned on the forums to fix the game.  I discovered that my save file was corrupted.  I can start a new character but at this point I'm far to ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and dissapointed in the developer for not fixing all the bugs to the original game before making a sequel that will probably be just as bug ridden.

Bottom Line__________________ AVOID THIS GAME.  There are numerous hack & slash games on the market that are far better so don't bother with this game it will just dissapoint and frustrate you.  It's quite unfortunate because I really wanted to like this game and was even planning on getting the sequel after finishing the first.  I doubt that will happen now."

reviewText:
- 9 / 10 -

Sweet game! nice graphics, particle & bloom effects with satisfying combat system. Unique companion leveling, skills & behaviours.

Voice acting & dialogue are quality for the most part, however a bit cheesy @ times. Storyline is plausibly good, unobtrusive but concise & allows for interesting main characters development. Great tunes & ambient tracks.

Quite the surprise coming from a movie-to-game! Fun RPG hack n slash!

reviewText: Well, this is going to be a very opinionated review. It may be due to the fact that i am not a very big fan of this type of game, but i did not find this game very satisfying. Even buying it when it was 70% off still leaves me wishing i had my six dollars back. Upon entry into the game i instantly began comparing it to Diablo III because i absolutely enjoyed that game to the fullest, and upon a dissappointing few first moments, i decided to give it a try none the less. After playing for a couple of hours, gaining quite a few levels, it became unbearable. Again, taking into account I don't usually play this type of game, it was just bland. Yes it offered lots of hack and slash action but it seems like too much of a rip off of Diablo, except with less depth. The game offers very little customization, and seemingly similar talents, which in the end, just leaves you with a boring grind for gear to defeat the final boss... not very impressed. 3/10 in my eyes

reviewText:
My Bite Sized Review - The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing

The Good:
+New game in the world of Van Helsing
+Controller Enabled
+Start the game with a companion that talks and can be used in combat
+A good amount of different playstyles
+Story through campanion banter is done well

The Bad:
-Graphics are very outdated
-Combat is very standard (melee, magic, or guns)
-Unlike Diablo 3 once you spend points into a build, you are stuck with it unless you pay gold to respec
-Enviroments are not that different (All kind of run together)
-Zombie AI (aka just run at character)
-Elite Mobs kill you quick, but themselves are just bullet sponges with average combat tactics
-In the late game, you are forced to just keep popping healing potions and mana to stay alive
-Quests are forgetable and not that interesting

The Verdict:

I will say I DO recommend this game if it is heavily discounted. Other than that though, this game is a very average diablo style role playing game. The combat and graphics show their age and mid to late game there is a boost in difficulty that I feel is very un-necessary. Like in Diablo 3 I understand that on Hell Difficulty it would be really hard, but here in this game mid way through enemies just start taking chunks out of you even though you have decent equipment. All in all a very average game that might not get recommended before some other games in the genre (For Example Titan Quest or Torchlight).

reviewText: A decent if somewhat monotonous Diablo style game. Not a lot I can say about it. You play as Van Helsing and have a female ghost AI companion; each level up in different ways. The story is unremarkable but well voiced. Enemies repeat VERY quickly and the latter half of the game is extremely drab looking. It's a mixed bag, but a passable title if you're looking for the Diablo formula.

reviewText: Would be a great hack'n'slash Diablo-clone game with witty banter and storyline if only it weren't for the frustratingly constant CTDs that lose your progress each time they occur.  Forums show many others having the same problem, and turning off Steam Saves did help significantly reducing the CTDs from every single time you made an area transition to once every 3 or 4 times, but that's still far too many CTDs that prevent you from enjoying an otherwise fun game. There were many other bugs that are unfixed in the game as well, but most of those have workarounds to resolve them in the Community Forums. I had decided to try to finish this game before buying the sequel, but never could finish because of the frequent CTDs, which honestly will keep me from buying the sequel. Truly sad because it was rather growing on me despite all the other bugs.

reviewText: The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is an average Action-RPG that is clearly outshone by other games in the genre. There are fair sized skill and talent trees that are hindered by limited hotkeys and level requirements. These trees allow for a multitude of ways to spend skill points and while it would imply replayability to neutralise the fact that there are only three classes, builds are far too restricted by the lack of available skill points and level restrictions. The three available classes are not very flexible in playstyle apart from the Hunter, but even that only has the choice to switch between melee and ranged. The combat has a focus on area-of-effect skills as the game can easily swarm you with monsters at ambiguous and undefined spawn points that can even be on top of you without warning. Loot drops occur too often and has uninteresting basic stat upgrades which taints the experience of obtaining new and better equipment. The plot is uninteresting and written poorly, the voice acting is subpar as they do not portray their characters' intent appropriately. The environments, despite varied, are cliche and does not compensate for the lack of world building that the plot, characters and ambience do not provide. Cooperative play is available but seems tacked on and is the same experience as the singleplayer, but with added players and monster difficulty.

reviewText:
Van Helsing is a good indie aRPG. I say indie, because if this had been released from a well known publisher it would have been treated as garbage and been on every 80% off sale it could find. Why do I say that? Well first let me just say that I wholly recommend this game! It's very fun and engaging. It presents a decent reward system. The graphics and sounds go along well with the pace of the action. So why call it garbage?

I didn't, I said it would have been treated as garbage had it been released from a big company. Van Helsing has bugs... Game breaking bugs wherein you can not complete main/storyline quests. Multiplayer bugs where games will just crash randomly or lag for no apparent reason or even spawn you into places where you are not supposed to reach thereby making you have to quit and return to the game. No tutorial for advanced features. Want to know how to upgrade (socket) items? So do I, go look for a youtube video, because this game honestly never tells you. The sounds, while going along well are somewhat repetative or campy. Also, the graphics, while they look well, enemies have a tendency to blend into the scene making it hard to know if you've killed everyone. It sports a strange control scheme and has no option to evade combat. If you're ranged and you get swarmed you can't run away because clicking in any direction means you're going to auto-attack. Also, if you have a controller plugged in, the game will not allow you to use a mouse and keyboard. You must exit, disconnect the controller, and restart the game.

Wooo... That was a long list of dislikes! I'm sorry, but I want you to know what you're getting into if you decide to purchase this title. Van Helsing has issues, BUT the game is fun! There is good dialogue and a story that makes sense. How many aRPG's have a story... and that makes sense!? The action is paced very well and never gets boring. There are quite a few quests to complete and I never had an issue figuring out where to go to complete them. Even though there are bugs the development team is working hard to correct them. Yes there are some instances where quests can't be completed, but until that's fixed, they've released a patch where you can bring up a console and complete the quest you're stuck on. The DLC classes provide more options. I like the Thaumaturge class. I'm very squishy, but I can take down the largest of monsters with ease.

So here's my final recommendation: If you like aRPG's and are looking for something to fill the gap between releases from big companies then I say grab this title. You will not be dissapointed. If aRPG's are not in your cup of tea, this game will not change your mind. If you are on the fence, just look over my comments about the bads and the goods. If you can live with the bads I think you'll find a lot of fun to be had here!

reviewText:
You like Diablo? You want more? Then you'll probably enjoy this game too.
Is the game better than Diablo (2-3)? No.
It is good enough and a worthy Diablo clone? Yes

Why is it good? What a Diablo clone needs is a good balance in loot drops, skills and enemies. Van Helsing has handled this pretty well. So it has nailed the most important part of the game. It also has an interesting steampunk/fantasy setting. But other than that, it doesn't really stand out much.

People had a few complaints about this game. I'll address them here:

Bugs
The release was buggy, but with the December patch things are running more smoothly. I've tried both singleplayer and co-op and it works fine.

Only 1 Class
The game features only 1 class: the hunter. Very meager, but the DLCs adds 2 more interesting classes. Still not a lot, but it has enough differences; each class is unique in skills and style.

reviewText:
This is a very fun ARPG. The play mechanics are excellent, the maps are huge, the quests are fun, and, for a lower budget game, the voice acting is quite nice. There are two DLCs thus far and for those who have the game, the dev has offered a unique item and an aura as a thank you.

Diablo, Torchlight, Grim Dawn, and other ARPG players will feel right at home with this game. There is a LOT of loot, a nice skill tree for your main character plus your ghost companion - she is a blast BTW with her snide and condescending remarks to Van Helsing. But, unlike the annoying companion in Legend: Hand of God, THIS companion is also a potentially gruesome, merciless killing machine. The DLC offers more replayability, but, even without it, you can play through the game again and specialize in different kinds of attacks - the same goes for your companion.

This game LOVES to swarm you and enemies will attack in all directions - it's absolutely glorious and at times, loot drops can be almost as crazy as Torchlight II.

I hope that Neocore will consider making a sequel. The game would easily compete with the best triple A ARPGs out there. A random map function would really round the game out.

Props to the devs who have been VERY responsive and have kept this jewel up to date. I am an ARPG fanatic and The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing is one of the most fun I am still playing.

reviewText:
I got this game for myself and a friend while it was on sale, and we've gotten some fun times out of it. My expectations were pretty low going in; I didn't really think that this game would be as much fun as it is. The writing and voice acting is pretty good, and I love the banter between your ghostly compainion, Lady Katarina, and Van Helsing.

From a gameplay perspective, everything seems to be well thought out and well balanced, but there are certain aspects (like the combo system) that I didn't really understand for a while (probably because I disabled the tutorial). One of my favorite things about the game is just how hard it can be sometimes. There are certain enemies that can kill you in just a few hits, so it becomes really important to use potions all the time (but don't worry... they drop off of anything and everything so you will have trouble running out).

One of the side-quests (to kill the hunter-machines) seems to be bugged for me, and I am not sure if all my skills are working the way they should (the upgrade to one of the skills should heal me each hit, but I can't really tell if it is working), but overall I love this game and think it's absolutely fantastic. The metascore clocks in at 72/100, which seems about right from a critical perspective, but the question I always ask myself is: Do I have fun playing this game, and how much fun am I having? The answer for The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing: Yes, this game is a blast and I am choosing to play it over the other games in my 181-game library on a nightly basis. Higly recommended for playing with friends (I haven't played solo).

reviewText: Surprisingly good game. It's got a lot of Diablo/Titan Quest kind of vibe but they take away a lot of annoying stuff and streamline it quite well. You're instantly given a permanent pet, and the ability to do both melee and ranged attacks. Meaning that you're basically every class at once. From there you just choose to specialize, better pets, better melee, better ranged, more magical, more physical. Depending on how you specialize is how the game unfolds.\n\nIt also has a sense of humor which I find refreshing and the voice acting is pretty decent. The plot is a bit weak but the gameplay, graphics and action is fun and impressive. All in all I was caught by surprise by this game and I do like it quite a bit. Fills that niche that Diablo III didn't quite fill.

reviewText: A quality aRPG that is sure to have gone under the radar of many. A unique story with a follower that levels alongside you, and many of the modern streamlining conveniences similar to Torchlight 2 that have their own added intricacies. Having only one class with others behind DLC is a bit bothersome, but the standard class is versatile on its own and the campaign is a good length. Postgame goes beyond the standard new game+ and adds especially hard challenge missions to the mix.  Overall, a must for the aRPG fan.

reviewText: The game is game is fun for the first 4 or so hours, with interesting enemies, nice visual effects and some witty voice acting from Katarina to go along side it all. The game seems very enjoyable at first but quickly deteriorates, the enemies become just tedious and you'll end up just trying to run past them to get to your objective. I played as the mage (or whatever name class is) and found that I could simply spam spells to enemy waves without any danger of dying. This simply takes away the intensity from the first few hours and creates a dull experience overall. The game does has some pleasing music, decent boss fights and the graphics aren't half bad. For me the journey stopped when nothing seemed to interest me/pose a real threat. I thought this was going to be a good dungeon crawler type game, unfortunately it wasn't for me and I hope they make a great sequel to correct these issues. 6.5/10

reviewText:
While it's fun to hear the dialogue between the ghost lady and your character on certain events, the slaying monster game play is quite boring. Most of the skill tree are auras or passives. There are very few interesting skills, which you can already tell by simply looking at the icon of the skill, the icons are copied and changed a bit for the next ones in the tree. The terrain is buggy on certain place, you're running but not moving. The environment looks nice and fresh however.

Exploring the map once was interesting but it isn't worth revisiting after. The two game modes after completing the game are mostly grinding.

The combat is definitely the weakest part of this game.

If it's on sales and you like RPG get it, play once then forget about it.
Otherwise, games like TL2, PoE and D3 are far more superior.

reviewText: I just beat the game on Heroic HC as a melee tank, then got one shot in the never-ending story" campaign by one of the first quest mobs. There is a lot to like about this game but also a lot not to like. First of all the game is not balanced in Heroic. Even if you want to play melee
date: you need to start as ranged or you will die. As you skill up and get gear you can go into melee.\n\nIn the second map I had problems surviving the earthquake mobs as melee
recommended:
a dev told me not get hit by the charging attacks. The thing is not all the mobs were charging thier attacks like they were supposed to. But after the 2nd map melee was viable.

The storyline ends so abruptly you are left wondering if it is over. The only signal that you finished is you have no more quests.
There is no real info on a lot of mechanics of the game
hoursPlayed:
nor is there a manual. Does MF on Katrina help the main char? Does Armor on Katrina help her in Ghost mode? Who knows?

I think the real unfortunate part of this game is that it is soo close to being really good. But instead of spending a little time on refinement they just moved onto the next game in the series.

As it stands now i can not recommed this game in Heroic Hardcore
voteText: but if you want to play casual its a decent game.\n"

reviewText:
This is a fun game. The story so far has been very solid and the voice acting is wonderful. It's amazing that I overlooked this game for so long.

Gameplay is a little repetitive, but in a good way. You have two sets of weapons, ranged and melee, but I find most of my time is spent kiting and using the ranged abilities on all but adds.

If you are a fan of Diablo or Path of Exile, you will like this game.

reviewText:
A LOT better than I originally thought it would be. When it was first released I was not at all interested, it looked cheap, generic, dull and just another fan fiction game with no substance. Damn, was I wrong. The base version only comes with one playable class(?) but with the DLC you can then choose from two more, the Thaumaturge which is basically your mage and the Arcane Mechanic wich is an engineer with cool gadgets.

Very different from most birds eye view RPG's I've played, different gearing and gemming mechanics and styles but it does not lack what only some can offer: a fun, changing, new, challenging, mass killing, awesome adventure.

The skill system works the same as most other games like this would, as you level up (killing monsteres, completeing quests, etc.) you gain skill poins, later on though you gain more per level but in turn your higher level abilities require more and one skill point (1, 2 and some 3). You have your main ability skills, (mostly activated and damaging abilities, some passive) Your Tricks ability page (special abilities that change or enhance game play [Thaumaturge can slow time for every thing around him, Arcane Mechanic can summon turrets, and other fun abilities]). And last are your Aura skills, you can have 2 auras on at a time that increase mana regen, critical damage boost, elemental damage increase, etc.

The game play, design, UI lay out and the game mechanics are very user friendly. One thing that most games lack is undoing skill point allocation. In this game you can remove points from skills one point at a time (for a fee, of course) so you don't totally throw you build out the window, you can instead make samll tweaks to it, which I love. You can do the same for you Ability points: Body(STR equiv) Dexterity(AGI euiv) Willpower (INT equiv) and Luck (magic item find, crit chance, dodge change modifier).

Your follower, Katarina, is a sassy spectre that helps out in battle but also adds a sense of humor to a seemingly bleak dark world. She has her own seperate Skillys and Abilities and you can change how she attacks and behave (Melee, Ranged, Passive while adding boosts to you). You can have her pick up items, and gold if you want, send her to town to do your shopping and she will back talk you the entire time. Different and weird at first, but she is a valuable asset to your goal of evil eradication.

There's a lot to say about this game, but you will just have to play it for your self to experience the fun and actually quite enjoyable graphics. There are some zones that feel laggy and I did have to tweak my video settings for it to be a little less glitchy at times (Running with two GTX 670 vid cards, i7 3.4Ghz, 16Gb RAM, 1 TB HD with a 240Gb SSD) my computer is more than capable of running any game at max graphics setting but I still experienced lag at times. Like any game, there are glitches and bugs that can some times even progression imparing, check the forums, the game has a built in repair function if a quest stops working or something similar, nothing major but it can be frustrating at times.

My over all verdict 8/10. Worth buying? Yes. Better with friends? Yes. I'ts a fun game and I have thoroughly enjoyed playing it.

reviewText: This is a hard game to review. On the one hand they do a lot of right things and on the other a lot of wrong things. The graphics are very nice and the sounds are good. The music is awful and I had to mute it. The music loops and its not very good.  The lore behind the game is original and the quests are fun for the most part.  The things I didnt like is the game is a lot harder then it should be. On Normal your going to be running for your life a lot of the time or least I was. I would say on normal for this game would be like hard or higher on Diablo 3. Mostly its because of the lack of regen on the armor stuff.\n\nThe casual mode is ok but a little to easy. I wouldnt mind something in between. The skill tree is still in my opinion is all over the place and messy to look at. I would like something like torchlight 2 or Diablo 3 more streamlined. You have auros, tricks, skill sets for melee or shooting and then you have subset skills  whithin the skills that you can activate via rage by fighting things. If that sounds confusing well it is. A lot more then it should. The Co Op seems to work fine for the person hosting more so then the joiner. I had a gambler inside my base the person who joined couldnt talk to him. A fun game but can be frusterating in a lot of small ways.  After playing this for a while I would give it a 7/10 some good ideas hampered by small issues. Just beat the game in Co-Op its a little buggy and there was some lag,  even on a lan? Go Figure.

reviewText:
If you've played Torchlight 2, you'll know what to expect.  The common root is Diablo, but The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing *is* Torchlight 2, to the extent that it feels like a rather underdone mod rather than a game in its own right.

That's fine, of course - inbreeding and cheeky rip-offs have always been rampant in the games industry.  It doesn't matter if a game resembles another, what matters is what it brings to the table.  Van Helsing comes up very short, sadly, and the best that can be said about it is that it'll remind you of better games from time to time.

Functionally it has everything you'd want from a game of this type, although it is a little buggy and nowhere near as configurable as it should be, but it feels like the work of people who got their game engine roughly working without any passion for the game they'd make with it.   It kind of pulls the right moves, but nothing really clicks.  Enemies are never exciting challenges, they're just pests who are either overpowered or underpowered, and combat is a constant annoyance.  A *constant* annoyance, as it never lets up - outside of safe town areas, fresh waves of enemies will always flood at you, which means that attempting to navigate the unnecessarily fussy character sheets, or even your inventory, will often result in death.

You will die often, but it'll rarely be the result of something you have or haven't done.  Sometimes it will be down to the nice but confusing art style that makes your character impossible to find on the screen, but generally it's down to this game having absolutely nothing to do at any turn other than a weak sigh and 'eh, throw more enemies in there?'

It's porridge floating in bathwater.  It's a game designed by people who don't understand games.  It's like eating a roll of wallpaper.  It is - and I don't say this lightly - perhaps the most tedious game I've ever played.  I go back to the Spectrum era, so I've seen some stinkers.  There's nothing here for anyone other than boredom.

reviewText: Before I get started with this review, I'll go ahead and point out that I'm not an expert. No really, loot-based action-rpgs aren't really my forte. Sure I've spent hundreds if not thousands of hours on titles like Diablo 2 and its ilk, but I couldn't tell you a dang thing about any of them. Go ahead and ask me about Diablo 2, all I recall is Tristram run after Blood run after Baal run after run after run after...bleah. I fried my brain on the genre years ago so I have just a little understanding for strategy"
recommended: and the inner-workings and mechanics of what makes this genre function. I still play them though because they're addictive as hell.\n\nNow then
hoursPlayed: what can I say about Van Helsing? Well
voteText: for starters the characters are a bit more amusing than most. This is one of the benefits of having a game where the main-characters stay the same no matter the class. Despite his appearance
helpfulPercent: Helsing is a good-humored dude
votesHelpful: and isn't always deadly serious about his job. His ghostly partner Katarina always has a cutting remark ready for the vampire hunter. As a duo they're far more memorable than most loot-clicker casts. I went with ranged-build
votesTotal: mostly relying on the spread-shot for crowd-control. Kat was built to violently explode upon "death" for great damage. It worked out well enough I suppose. I played on hard difficulty and didn't run into many problems (didn't beat the game
votesFunny: more on that later).\n\nVan Helsing plays out much the same as any other loot-clicker. You have your equipment
commentsCount: your rares
column16: your skills
column17: and your build. Either through happenstance or a guide you find your build
column18: you choose the right skills for it
column19: allocate the appropriate stats
column20: then just kill stuff for appropriate weapon upgrades. For some gamers
column21: that's compelling enough on its own
column22: but it's preferable to hunt for something more.\n\nWhere Van Helsing falters is mostly in the map-design. Each area is largely uninteresting. Some areas (like the ink realm) are visually inventive
column23: but that's about it. The maps in this game are largely just a lot of space filled with packs of enemies. Nothing really changes as you progress. In the forest you'll run into packs of wolves
column24: somewhere else there will be packs of soldiers
column25: or packs of demons
column26: and so on. When monsters are grouped together like that the game becomes stagnant. After you've found your build you're not likely to use more than the same or 2 or 3 skills at all times. Variety isn't just fighting different monsters
column27: it's fighting monsters that approach in different ways. Some should ambush
column29: hell maybe they're just wandering around. In this game
column30: they just wait around in organized groups for a vampire hunter to come fight them. One particular area is also aggravating because it is split into two sections
column31: which leads to several minutes (slight exaggeration) of wandering back to square one if you go the wrong way. I will give credit to one area in that portions of it are separated by chasms
column32: so enemies can take pot-shots at you as you try to cross. Sure it's headache-inducing
column33:
but at least it's inducing a feeling of something more and not just "oh look. All these monsters are standing around for the thousandeth time" mediocrity.

...But I didn't quit the game yet.

A real frustrating aspect of this game involves the hit mechanics. More precisely
column35: what constitutes a hit? When I see an enemy wind-up to attack -- pull their fist back
column36: hold an axe over their head
column37: etc. -- I should be able to move out of the way to dodge it. Loot-Clickers..no...Action-RPGs in general have dozens of stats
column38: even a dodge rating. All the same
column39: there should be an incentive for players to avoid attacks through direct-input
column40: not just their number > the enemy's number. Van Helsing flicks a toothpick at that idea
column41:
and it is a consistent source of annoyance for me. Even when I'm clear out of the way of an attack I'll still take damage.

But that's not why I quit the game.

After a certain point Van Helsing is given control of a resistance base
column42: and he can outfit it as he sees fit. This is basically the tower defense portion of the game and THANKFULLY it's largely optional. I put the emphasis on THANKFULLY because I hated it that much. I'm going to change subjects ever so slightly and talk about a PS2 game called Shining Force Exa. In this game there is a fortress that is regularly attacked. While one character is questing
column43: the other holds down the fort (so to speak). When you strip enough elements away from tower-defense you're left with nothing but "protect this thing". However if the core of the game is entertaining enough
column44: that doesn't really matter. I actually enjoyed these battles in Exa because they focused on the core. A lot of monsters were thrown at the player and that was the extent of it. Van Helsing has this whole set-up where you can buy traps and place them all over this corridor-abundant dungeon. The waves of enemies are too frequent
column46: and due to the way the dungeon is constructed you'll never reach them in time. You have to approach these battles almost entirely with a tower-defense mindset. This isn't what I signed up for when I started playing Van Helsing. To be fair
column47: tower-defense was a hardly a thing when Exa came out
column48:
but really who wants to play that crap when they pick up an action-RPG?

...But I didn't quit the game at that point. After all the tower-defense stuff is largely optional.

No I didn't actually quit Van Helsing until I was maybe one or two dungeons away from the final boss. When Katarina had reached her level-cap
column49: and Helsing was maybe one or two levels away from his
column51: of all the things to quit a game over it's due to hitting a level-cap. Or maybe the real reason is because it dawned on me that this is only part one of Van Helsing's incredible adventures. I'm sure if I picked up the second game I'd get to continue leveling
column52: to continue fighting in seemingly endless repetitive encounters
column53: using the same skills I mastered hours ago
column55: and there'd probably be even more tower-defense garbage. I didn't think myself capable of stomaching another 15-20 hours of a sequel to this game
column56: so I quit.\n\nI'll give credit where it's due
column57: Van Helsing managed just enough in getting the basics down to keep me playing. I'm an exceptional case though
column58: I play a lot of loot-clickers regardless of quality
column59: so maybe my judgment isn't always sound. If I see yellows
column61: and golds dropping at a decent enough rate there's no telling what games I could be tricked into playing. It's only when the end of the road is in sight do I realize that maybe this game isn't for me and move on. This is where Van Helsing lies. It's not particularly bad
column62: but it gave me reason enough to quit as soon as I shook out of its icy grip."

reviewText:
I could tell you so many things about this game.

How it is charming, funny, addictive and actually has combat that is satisfying and weighty.

I could tell you how this is the anti-Torchlight and anti-Diablo 3 in that it actually improves the ARPG genre by its mere existence.  That it isn't a cashgrab and it harkens back to the days when games were actually designed and had love and care put into them.

How it is neither an evolution" or "revolution" of the genre (or any other buzzword for that matter)
date:
but just a damn good game for once.


But the only thing I need to tell you is that Abed from Community is the final boss.

Happy hunting.  Best $20 you'll spend on Steam."

reviewText: This game should be called The Incredible Adventures of DLC Hell-sing. The first thing you come across when creating your first character are three classes - two of which are, of course, disabled unless you have bought the additional DLC. Fine, you select your hunter (as if you had ever wanted to play a guy with a tin can on his head) and venture forth into this wonderful world! You kill a few creatures, kill a few thugs and ding! - you have leveled up. Imagine the joy when you open the character tree and see that - is it even possible? - even some of the hunter's skills are disabled. Unless you've paid even more money for the game, that is. Yeah, no.

reviewText:
The overall interaction between two main characters seems interesting however,

1. bad optimization: game interfering input lags and freezing even at the lowest setting (I have 1 year old iMac)
Additionally, the characters have inconsistant frame rates, bigger mobs seem to have 10 to 15-fps attacking animation while having little bit higher fps for walking animation...etc. (very noticeable)
2. bad options menus: windows mode isn't properly supported. It still opens in fullscreen mode and alt-tab doesn't work.
3. unfriendly to new players: crucial game mechanics such as switching skill sets" (press tab) aren't anywhere to be found
recommended: tooltips don't explain enough.\n4. combat mechanic is... odd. You can't lose aggro from mobs therefore when you start kiting or running away
hoursPlayed: you'll find yourself aggro-ing too many mobs

reviewText:
THis game  could have easliy been a lot better.

One of the silly mistakes that they did is they have 3 classes to choose from But they are all Van Helsings just in different clothes.. They Might as well have stuck with one character and given him a tree allowing he to learn everything..

In my opinion this game is  like a budget Diablo 3 But no where near as good. I will compare it to Diablo 3 throughout this review to give you a gadge since you have most probably played Diablo 3.

Only really one character to choose from with a different skin and different item & skill sets
In Diablo 3 there are about 5 or 6 charactors to choose from

The graphics are no where near as good as Diablo 3.

The game gets boring a lot quicker the Diablo 3 did. As you can see I only have 1.7 hours on record.. That is because I  really could'nt be bothered playing any further Because its not a good game.

Even if I try to justify it not being at the same level as Diablo 3  By saying this game only cost $14.95 and diablo 3 is $90, there are still better free options like path of exile and much better options at simular prices like Torch light 2..

I took a chance on this game because I got it for a $1 from HumbleBundle.com in one of their weekly sales so I dont feel bad about buying this game. But I would feel a but annoyed if I had paid $14.95

Therefore I can not recomend this game.

If you really want to try it even after reading this review maybe buy it if it pops
up again in one of the charity bundles or goes on sale at the steam store for 80-90% off or something.
But don't pay full price for this or you will be disapointed

reviewText:
It is an okay game, with a few issues, that can drive you crazy.
My biggest gripe is that you can get one shot so often, it is not even remotely funny. And you really cannot do anything about it. I had a lot of body as a ranged character, which increases your HP, but all the Health and Dodge Chance did not help with it. At some point the game just gives it to you up the butt.

If you are used to Diablo or Torchlight, the combat also seems kind of bland. There is not a lot of feedback of you are out of mana or rage, the combat itself is not really visceral or meaty.

It is still worth a playthrough if you are into Van Helsing though and their support is outstanding actually.

reviewText: Put on your wide-brimmed hat, grab your weapons and embark on an incredible adventure in the gothic-noir world of Borgovia, where mad science threatens the fragile peace between monster and mortal. Be Van Helsing, monster-hunter extraordinaire and save the day with your charming and beautiful companion, Lady Katarina (who happens to be a ghost, by the way). Explore the savage wilderness in the mountains and the soot-stained brick districts of a grim metropolis twisted by weird science, and don’t forget: you might never know who the real monsters are!
voteText: 1 of 15 people (7%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is a great game with great characters, soundtrack and story. This is a classic hack and slash style game with different skill trees to improve your character in different ways. Unfortunately there is only one base class which is Hunter, and to get other classes you need to buy the DLCs which is a pain. Yet this doesn't take away the level of fun because there are different ways to play this one class. You want to go range? Upgrade your gunslinging skills and fire away. Melee? Upgrade your blades and hack and slash your way through the game.

There is a down-side, you will die A LOT and it costs A LOT to revive. Maybe its because I'm a noob, but I advise you that you will be swarmed with enemies. So really your going through the entire game shooting explosive rounds until they die. Your ghost partner in the game isnt all that useful. You will find yourself walking along then suddenly Katarina attacks something and you get swarmed with bad guys.

Yet this game is great, I love and I just can't get enough of it. I advise you to buy the other classes because they come with different skill trees and weapons. The other classes consit of the Thaumaturge which is basicly a mage and Acane Mechanic, which gives you big ♥♥♥ guns that shoot electricity.

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. But its flaws are very blatant and ruined the experience for me.
It's the UI. You have different inventories for types of items E.G Hats,Weapons, Armor ETC. And overall it's clunky and confusing.
Another glaring issue are the controls. you NEED a gamepad to play this. or get ready to rebind everything. It's an ARPG on PC and Neocore missed the core ease of controls for this genre.  Point and click controls. They could have implemented. The classes are interesting and the setting is unique. Combat is solid, but at least for me it didn't matter what settings the game runs at it looked the same. Framerate is capped by default to 30fps but this can be turned off (thankfully). VO is average if not a bit corny.
The game just isn't cohesive in terms of mechanics.
Do yourself a favor and download Path of Exile, It's free and WAY better then this. Or Diablo, Or Torchlight. Really any ARPG on pc that gets things right!

reviewText:
Don't buy this game, if you want to play in CO-OP. It's too buggy, you will get freezes every 15 minutes, you will need to load again because one of your mates didn't save the quest progress.
I really like this game, it's fun to play with a gamepad, but it's simply unplayable in coop. Everytime someone else than the host joins a new area first, his game freezes. Sometimes if you die, port back to town, you freeze. Sometimes your spells don't work, sometimes you port, but the game freezes. I played the game with 2 friends, everyone had the same issues, we searched for possible solutions like compabilty mode, worse graphics etc. still the same problems. it's really annoying since the game is out over a year already and most of the bug threads are older than a year. it's really dissapointing since it might be a really nice game, but without any support (and i guess there wont be any fixes - they prefered to release the second game with obviously the same bugs (just google for it)) its crap.
Me and my friends won't support this company again. It's pretty cheecky to advertise this game as CO-OP"
"

reviewText:
Becomes too boring after one Playtrough, also especially if you want get all Achievements its boring and there are not enough Enemy to kill, thats why i spend 177 Hours with this Crap to finally reach the 500'000 Kills.

Because i was really bored already, i used a Wrench on the Controller to hold the Button down, positioned the Character to kill endless respawning Monsters in Front, for almost 24 Hours to reach the 500'000 Kills also because the Game became slower and slower because the Bodys was not removed, i was forced to use an Attack that desintegrate them, Boring, Boring, Boring!

So i can only recommend it partially for one Playtrough, but there is no Replayvalue other than boring Grinds for the boring Achievements probably made only to artificially lengthen the Completion - BORING!

Did i already mention this Game is Boring?

Also the most Boring Thing is limited Storage, its only 4x your Inventory Space(with Perk), so you will spend alot of Time with boring sorting out good stuff to replace it with a little better stuff.

I can't recommend it because i can't stand limited Storage in Games where Loot is a Core-Component.

I hardly managed to put all my Epics i got into the Storage and there was no Duplicates, so Storage is defintely too small. Period.

And Games with limited Storage like this, will get an automatically Not Recommended" by me

reviewText: This game has pretty stunning visuals, and before starting I had a lot of high hopes for it, and expected gameplay to complementary the beautiful graphics very well. And sadly, it doesn't exactly. Combats don't feel very exciting, and so far it's pretty much the typical RPG grindfest for gold (well what was I expecting?). The existence of decent equipment from shops  and the exorbitant prices isn't a very nice design touch, as it creates shallow treadmill goals that encourage mindless grinding.\n\nAn upside though is that with that price this game is quite a steal. Not as good as I expected, but I don't regret the purchase. I will most definitely explore the game some more. If you're a newcomer of the genre and looking for a great WRPG/ARPG experience to get your feet wet then I think this game isn't really for you. But if you've hard into the genre then this game is quite a decent one and worth trying for the price it's asking for.
